strategy.title: Does digital service goals subscribe to one of SDG (Sustainable Development Goals) ?
strategy.test: Does the service cover at least one of the 17 SDG ?
strategy.description: It is required to ensure the service is compliant with at least one of the 17 SDG, in order to avoid services without real value.

strategy.title: Is the business need expressed ?
strategy.test: Are business needs assessed impartially in relation to uses?
strategy.description: Uncertainties encourage to extrapolate needs often beyond real expectations, which is harmful for environmental footprints.
strategy.score: Framing redacted and validated = 100 ; Framing formalized = 75 ; gentlemen agreement = 30 ; No = 0 / 100

strategy.title: Are the sponsors and any resistance to the Sustainable IT approach identified ?
strategy.test: Have you anticipated the resistance by setting out the arguments regarding the obstacles to the implementation of the approach: foreseeable obstacles, motivation, poor internal communication, management with little involvement, other heavy and priority projects, heavy and recent investments, regulations ,. ..?
strategy.description: When the Sustainable IT approach is little installed in the operational model of the organization, struggles for influence will sometimes decide the future of Sustainable IT. To facilitate adoption, the brakes must be identified and the arguments to overcome resistance must be prepared in advance and made available to the sponsors of this approach.

strategy.title: Are the Sustainable IT objectives clearly stated and shared by all stakeholders, internal or external to the organization ?
strategy.test: Have you set up a formal communication of Sustainable IT objectives, accessible to all stakeholders?
strategy.description: Several actors, including those from outside the organization, can be involved in the project. The permeability of the Sustainable IT approach towards all stakeholders can identify / activate levers that stakeholders may not have spontaneously expressed.
strategy.score: Information broadcasting channels / Number of stakeholders

strategy.title: Are the implementation deadlines envisaged ?
strategy.test: Have you quantified the benefits / over-costs of the Sustainable IT approach on the project schedule?
strategy.description: Managing project deadlines is always a central concern. So that Sustainable IT is not the element pointed out, the deadlines (more or less) linked to this approach must be expressed. The project deadline only occurs once in the life of the service, the sustainable IT gain or debt of the project will multiply throughout the life cycle of the project.

strategy.title: When remote meetings are not possible, are they limited to the strict minimum when physical travel is required ?
strategy.test: Do the tools exist in the company to allow remote meetings in good conditions?
strategy.description: Travels are sources of Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and have an impact on the personal organization of employees.
strategy.score: Meeting from distance / Total Number of meetings

strategy.title: Is teleworking allowed, without limits, to employees who want it and whose activity allows it ?
strategy.test: Does the company offer a framework for teleworking?
strategy.description: In addition to the limitation of commuting and its environmental footprint, time lost during travel can be considerable. On the other hand, the tools and the organization must avoid the breakdown of social ties that can result from teleworking.
strategy.score: Number of teleworking proposals / Concerned positions

strategy.title: Is the company open to a Sustainable IT approach which could unite spirits around an innovative project ?
strategy.test: Do managers have a free hand to initiate the Sustainable IT approach in projects?
strategy.description: To be effective, the Sustainable IT approach must be present in the organisation's strategy and involve all decision-making processes with the aim of reducing the impact of digital services.

strategy.title: Are the CSR and Sustainable IT strategies associated and systematically implemented in all projects ?
strategy.test: What proportion of projects have Sustainable IT requirements?
strategy.description: Sustainable IT treatment is a systemic approach that has to be considered in all projects. As it is often the case for CSR, the gain is much more significant than when Sustainable IT elements are dealt with on an ad hoc basis.

strategy.title: How to make Sustainable IT more than a communication objective ?
strategy.test: Are Sustainable IT requirements taken into account by all projects' teams?
strategy.description: The energy and budgets spent on purely communicating aspects (greenwashing) can be substantial for no tangible result. With the same investments it is possible to obtain significant results on which communication will be more effective.

strategy.title: Is the target of users (primary and secondary) defined, to specify the business need ?
strategy.test: Are the users' profiles described with the corresponding USE CASE?
strategy.description: In order to respond accurately (neither too much nor too little) to user expectations, it is essential to know the targets and their behavior, so as not to overload the applications, nor to impoverish them to the point that they no longer meet the legitimate expectations. Secondary users often have simpler needs. Without identifying this category of user, it is difficult to properly size the service.

strategy.title: Are the users' materials identified ?
strategy.test: Is each USE CASE associated with the list of hardware equipment necessary for its implementation?
strategy.description: Certain uses may be constrained by user equipment, to allow a wider choice of equipment, even old ones, and to limit equipment renewals. It is important to know the hardware profiles that users will be able to use, today and in the future.

strategy.title: Are all products and services essential online ?
strategy.test: Can the product / service be envisioned without being deployed online, with a similar outcome for the business?
strategy.description: Some functionalities are offered in connected mode while no remote data or no heavy calculation process is required. In these cases, a local (offline) solution is environmentally efficient, with fewer information flow and use of networks. On the other hand, if the offline mode requires duplication of information, it is only justified if the network accesses are intermittent and pose difficulties in using the service.

strategy.title: Can I cover the needs differently, by avoiding digital through a more environmentally friendly mean ?
strategy.test: Can the product / service be envisioned without being digital, with a similar result for the company?
strategy.description: Some simple manual processes can be an alternative to everything digital, even within a digital department. In the context of a digital service, the natural tendency is to integrate all the steps into it without asking the question of environmental efficiency.
strategy.score: Number of Formalized questions / Number of requirements

strategy.title: Is the chosen solution the most environmentally friendly ?
strategy.test: Have you expressed alternative scenarios and assessed the Sustainable IT impact of each one of them?
strategy.description: The new service can bring better environmental efficiency, but it can also participate in the creation of additional environmental debt. All 3 dimensions (3P) must be able to show a benefit otherwise the positioning of the service may need to be reviewed.

strategy.title: Does this service's business model take eco-design into account ?
strategy.test: Is the adaptation of the business model being considered to take eco-design into account?
strategy.description: When Sustainable IT is outside the business model, it is difficult to reconcile economic activity and Sustainable IT impacts, and this most often turns into trade-offs where immediate prosperity is favored over 3P.

strategy.title: Are performance, accessibility, safety and sobriety aspects taken into account together ?
strategy.test: What decision rules are specified to optimize my digital service by mixing sobriety and performance?
strategy.description: In most cases, better technical performance is also synonymous with better environmental efficiency, the consumption of computing resources is lower, the transfer volumes are smaller, the algorithms are more efficient.

strategy.title: Are the Sustainable IT gains evaluated prior to the project ?
strategy.test: Have you quantified the environmental benefit of the project by doing eco-design or by deciding to avoid digital?
strategy.description: In the case of a service overhaul, it is easier to estimate the gains expected by the new service with reference to the current service. For a new service, the preliminary study will determine the savings hypotheses which will have to be refined during the project. The display of expected gains is an important marker to convince all stakeholders of the merits of the approach.

strategy.title: Is Sustainable IT part of the organisation's strategy and objectives ?
strategy.test: Are all decision-making bodies ready to develop an eco-designed digital service in your organization at this time? Does the organisation's financial strength allow it to innovate?
strategy.description: To enable a Sustainable IT approach in projects, it is essential that all decision-makers adhere to it, which is necessarily the case if Sustainable IT is part of the organisation's strategy. Otherwise, it will be difficult to carry out a Sustainable IT approach, because it will constantly be necessary to find justifications to continue that way. The project would be impacted and therefore perceived as less effective "because of the Sustainable IT".

strategy.title: Are market expectations, customers, suppliers and partners in line with a Sustainable IT approach ?
strategy.test: Have you carried out a market study to validate stakeholders' expectations with regard to Sustainable IT?
strategy.description: The different sectors of activity have varying sensitivities to Sustainable IT, and for the same scope, certain organizations or categories of stakeholders have varying aspirations. Committing to a Sustainable IT approach and exposing it is easier if it corresponds to an issue for the given actors. The communication and expression of the Sustainable IT approach will be somewhat different depending on the maturity of the targetted market.

strategy.title: Are the challenges and expected benefits clearly identified ?
strategy.test: Have you quantified the financial (cost reduction, increase in turnover) and non-financial (communication, environment, innovation, standing out from the competition) gains?
strategy.description: To capitalize on the innovation brought by Sustainable IT, it is important to determine the benefits of the approach, whether from a financial point of view,of competitive advantage of notoriety or of communication capacity. and recognition of being a committed player to reduce the impact of digital technology.

strategy.title: Is the organization able to become more mature with respect to eco-design and its scope, with the realization of Sustainable IT projects ?
strategy.test: What proportion of project stakeholders are aware of or trained in Sustainable IT?
strategy.description: The Sustainable IT approach must be present in all stages of implementation and this necessarily requires a Sustainable IT culture within the organization. Maturity will gradually increase with practice.

strategy.title: Is an audit of the existing service available to improve its Sustainable IT performance ?
strategy.test: Do you need to audit what already exists in order to improve the project or do you have to start from scratch?
strategy.description: The main defaults of an existing service compared to the 3P can usefully serve as a basis for determining the areas where Sustainable IT performance can be improved with quick wins and deeper adaptations.

strategy.title: Are the financial budgets for the IT Sustainable aspects of the project evaluated ?
strategy.test: Do I have the material means? Is my equipment to renew or purchased and what will be the most ecological way to do it? Are human resources identified for each phase of the project? Are the financial means to carry out the eco-design project allocated?
strategy.description: Sustainable IT will generate a new category of requirements that will have to be considered while approaching a project, and will require clearly identified budget lines. Although  Sustainable IT projects are often more efficient, less "bulimic" of "trendy" technologies and useless functionalities, the project loads in the end are reduced.

strategy.title: Is material equipment to be renewed or purchased for the project, is the necessary additional equipment made available keeping in mind the principles of Sustainable IT ?
strategy.test: Does the material purchase / renewal policy take into account Sustainable IT efficiency?
strategy.description: The launch of new projects is often an opportunity to renew or supplement technical equipment. In line with the Sustainable IT approach, it would be the occasion to challenge a better use of the available equipment and to implement all possible solutions to preserve it.

strategy.title: Are my human resources (identified for each phase) available ?
strategy.test: Are the necessary Sustainable IT awareness-raising / training budgeted and planned?
strategy.description: The effectiveness of the Sustainable IT approach cannot be achieved without knowledge of the Sustainable IT issues by the people who will take part in the project.

strategy.title: Are internal and external stakeholders aware of, or even trained / certified in Sustainable IT ?
strategy.test: What training budget is allocated by type of profile?
strategy.description: Each stakeholder needs effective information on their area of ​​expertise and action, only an adapted training plan can provide this effectiveness upstream of projects.
strategy.score: Number of Sustainable IT Awareness / Number of Staff member

strategy.title: Do we have the people with the most relevant technical skills for each element of the project ?
strategy.test: How many actors in each stage of the project have Sustainable IT training?
strategy.description: The Sustainable IT approach requires above all a strong business practice. It is difficult to optimize technical elements when the practice is not sufficiently anchored. Conversely, Sustainable IT optimizations are sometimes "counter-intuitive" and a good mastery of Sustainable IT and 3P is essential.
strategy.score: Number of Trained to Sustainable IT / Number of team members

strategy.title: Are the Sustainable IT referents listed and the list communicated to the actors of the project ?
strategy.test: Who are the official referents of the project in terms of eco-design? internally or externally?
strategy.description: Sustainable IT addresses a very large perimeter, which is difficult to fully understand in each phase of a project. It is essential that the professionals involved in the project can be assisted at all times by referents to deploy the best practices.

strategy.title: Is a strategy to raise the awareness of colleagues / partners / clients to Sustainable IT in place with steps allowing continuous improvement in practices ?
strategy.test: Is the Sustainable IT training plan implemented and followed?
strategy.description: The adoption of Sustainable IT is a global approach, which should not be hampered by the ability to do everything right away, it is part of a progression that sets in as the practice progresses.

strategy.title: Were the teams questioned before the launch of the project, was the impact assessed and communicated ?
strategy.test: Are team feedback reviewed and discussed to improve Sustainable IT processes?
strategy.description: When Sustainable IT approach is integrated into the project management, component improvement feature is reached. Thus, project adapts itself and related processus to sustainability thanks to feebacks.

strategy.title: Do each internal and external stakeholders have the latitude to make decisions that may influence the impact of Sustainable IT ?
strategy.test: Is the decision-making circuit and autonomy having a Sustainable IT impact defined for each actor?
strategy.description: Project decisions that can have a significant impact on the environment must be able to be taken quickly. For this, it is essential to define the decision-making space of each actor and the validation mechanisms. In the absence of this clarification, erratic decisions, even for good reasons, could intervene and discredit the Sustainable IT approach, or lead to a form of self-censorship limiting the Sustainable IT benefits.

strategy.title: Do we have the people with the most relevant technical skills for each element of the project ?
strategy.test: How many actors in each stage of the project have Sustainable IT training?
strategy.description: The Sustainable IT approach requires above all a strong business practice. It is difficult to optimize technical elements when the practice is not sufficiently anchored. Conversely, Sustainable IT optimizations are sometimes "counter-intuitive" and a good mastery of Sustainable IT and 3P is essential.
strategy.score: Number of Trained to Sustainable IT / Number of team members

strategy.title: Will the project with a Sustainable IT approach really meet the needs of my customers ?
strategy.test: Do you measure customer satisfaction on Sustainable IT aspects?
strategy.description: A Sustainable IT approach applied to a digital service can in some cases generate a little discomfort / disruption for users in their practices. A support or communication mechanism can easily address these points. And bring a significant valuation.

strategy.title: Are Sustainable IT aspects propagated and maintained across all stakeholders ?
strategy.test: What is your frequency of Sustainable IT communication for each stakeholder profile?
strategy.description: Obtaining and maintaining the commitment of stakeholders is an important point for Sustainable IT to become the de facto standard.

strategy.title: Is sustainable IT compliance exposed to users ?
strategy.test: Is "Sustainable IT statement" available for the service?
strategy.description: Digital service built to be compliant with sustainable IT recommendations must report strength and weakness identified. This should be done in the same way as accessibility report delivered in the "accessibility statement" page on web sites.
strategy.score: Document validated and exposed = 100 ; Partall = 50 ; Planned = 25 ; No = 0 / 100

strategy.title: Are each of the life cycle phases (start-up, maturity, shutdown) identified with specific actions ?
strategy.test: Have you listed all the actions associated with Sustainable IT for the different project stages?
strategy.description: The LCA approach is a basis for taking into account Sustainable IT in the design of digital services. It allows actions to be associated with each stage of the life cycle.

strategy.title: Are LCA data reused in case of of an adaptation of an existing service ?
strategy.test: Have you made previous LCAs available to the project teams?
strategy.description: LCA analyzes can be carried out on existing services in order to make them more efficient in the case of a redesign or adaptation of an existing service.

strategy.title: If I decide to redo my service, what do I keep of the old one and how do I clean it from the canvas ?
strategy.test: Are the reusable parts of the old site described?
strategy.description: Good optimization of Sustainable IT issues also involves the reuse of elements that have been designed with a consideration for Sustainable IT in order to avoid duplicating certain elements or having duplicate, or simply inactive, components which would only be maintained because the cleaning effort was not considered.

strategy.title: Can I recycle software component or existing content ?
strategy.test: Is there a repository of shared software bricks (authentication, user account base, generic interconnection APIs, etc.)?
strategy.description: Modular design is a widely used business practice. Sustainable IT can benefit from these methods when each modular component is well described and its strengths or weaknesses are well identified.

strategy.title: How are the end-of-life phases managed, from the start or at the end of a project ?
strategy.test: Have you listed all the de-provisioning procedures?
strategy.description: During design, each part of the project may have to possess different lifespans. It is important that all end-of-life procedures are expressed so that the footprint of unused and disabled components is zero.

strategy.title: Is awareness of "non-quality costs" shared by all internal stakeholders ?
strategy.test: Are the quality defects recorded, analyzed and also dealt with on the Sustainable IT axis?
strategy.description: The quality of the software produced has a direct impact on Sustainable IT aspects. Indeed, the defects generate multiple deliveries of successive new versions, the anomalies lead to the production of significant anomalies traces, and functionalities that consume more technical resources, sometimes for an unfulfilled result, therefore resources have been wasted for no results.

strategy.title: During an audit, are the following elements taken into account ?
strategy.test: Is energy consumption measured for each typical route on the site?
strategy.description: When the user journey is short, fewer components are implemented, flows are reduced, the service is easier to understand, so the Sustainable IT aspects are better taken into account.
strategy.score: Number of path analyzed / Number of User journey

strategy.title: Are the indicators to measure the effectiveness of my Sustainable IT approach identified and monitored ?
strategy.test: What indicators are defined to measure the effectiveness of my Sustainable IT approach?
strategy.description: The measurement of certain elements is an objective which makes it possible to enhance the result of a Sustainable IT approach. The search for overly complex indicators can be counterproductive, it is better to focus on reliable and significant data and to change the number and precision of indicators as the organization and internal actors gain in maturity.

strategy.title: Are the tools to measure the effectiveness of my Sustainable IT approach identified and communicated ?
strategy.test: What tools have been selected to measure the effectiveness of my Sustainable IT approach?
strategy.description: Allowing actors to validate the results obtained by taking into account Sustainable IT is important because it allows everyone to take ownership of this approach and to situate their actions in this objective with tools adapted to each actor.

strategy.title: Is the project's lifetime defined ?
strategy.test: Have you estimated the period during which the service will be useful?
strategy.description: A digital service can no longer be designed for eternity, it is closely linked to socio-economic environments. Thus, it should be able to question it regularly. This also has the advantage of not accumulating technical debts and of staying abreast of the most effective advances and practices in the areas of Sustainable IT which evolve very quickly.

strategy.title: Are the experiences of past projects taken into account ?
strategy.test: How many post-mortem projects do you have available to capitalize on previous achievements?
strategy.description: Many projects within an organization have common principles, it is necessary to be able to rely on other projects to capitalize on the gains and benefits of Sustainable IT approaches of the past, and to enrich them with new knowledge or acquired practices.

strategy.title: Are there plans to capitalize on the experience of this project for the future ?
strategy.test: What documentary production is associated with the project for the Sustainable IT aspects?
strategy.description: Project methodologies frequently use postmortems to learn from past achievements and move forward. Sustainable IT must appear in these themes.

strategy.title: Do the indicators cover the elements for measuring, evaluating and estimating the level of Sustainable IT maturity, managing it, improving it and controlling it ?
strategy.test: Are the data sources for the indicators reliable?
strategy.description: The Sustainable IT approach is iterative, it must be part of a process of continuous improvement.

strategy.title: Apart from the elements constituting the digital service, what are the necessary ancillary services: third-party / open source technology, green hosting, eco-responsible digital agency ... ?
strategy.test: Is the technical annex of the project formalized?
strategy.description: The design, development and production phases have impacts on Sustainable IT aspects which must be addressed in all the resources associated with the project.

strategy.title: Is each function of the service understood in terms of its importance in the service ?
strategy.test: Have you applied an 80/20 approach for each function in relation to its environmental footprints and its importance?
strategy.description: The most important functions sometimes consume less resources than marginal functions, which does not make sense in a coherent Sustainable IT approach.

strategy.title: Is regulated data (health, banking, etc.) used throughout the system ?
strategy.test: Is each regulated data justified and identified?
strategy.description: The user's exposure must be able to be strictly controlled. Beyond regulation, it is also the human dimension of Sustainable IT that is at stake.

strategy.title: Are personal data within the GDPR scope used ?
strategy.test: Is each personal data listed and managed?
strategy.description: The user entrusts you with data. To take the PEOPLE aspect into consideration, and not to expose yourself to costly sanctions, the Sustainable IT approach encourages a strong limitation of this data.

strategy.title: Is the choice of Open Source solutions preferred ?
strategy.test: What Sustainable IT metrics do you have for the proposed Open Source solutions?
strategy.description: An Open Source solution is not a guarantee of Sustainable IT efficiency and the different alternatives must be challenged. But open source makes it possible to limit the ambitions and control of certain actors whose economic and social practices are opaque.

strategy.title: Do the integrated tools (CMS, frameworks, ...), or internal developments, bring positive elements to the Sustainable IT approach ?
strategy.test: What Sustainable IT metrics do you have for the solutions deployed internally?
strategy.description: In the BUY / BUILD choices, the Sustainable IT dimension should be assessed and projected over time to ensure that the choices are sufficiently scalable to gain Sustainable IT compliance over time. And not only on the development / integration phase.

strategy.title: Which technology adhering to Sustainable IT principles is most appropriate for my needs ?
strategy.test: Do you have a grid of criteria for evaluating the technological alternatives available?
strategy.description: The technological choice must be dictated by Sustainable IT criteria, rather than by the technological appeal of the trendy novelty. To have a broader vision, the list of criteria must be determined by a collective not exclusively made up of technicians who will use them.

strategy.title: In the case of internal development (CMS, Framework, ...), what is the relevance of reworking it from the angle of Sustainable IT optimization, if the Sustainable IT approach is poorly mastered and the project is already advanced ?
strategy.test: Is the cost of upgrading of the solutions deployed internally, with respect to the Sustainable IT, quantified?
strategy.description: The tools selected for the developments must enable the integration of Sustainable IT principles without a complex overhaul being necessary. The complexity parts goodwill and discards the less experienced people, which gives the project an elitist form not very compatible with the Sustainable IT principles.

strategy.title: How to choose the most suitable technical solutions for Sustainable IT ?
strategy.test: Have you listed the rules that make it possible to arbitrate the technical choices, for example: the training load compared to the Sustainable IT gain, the medium and long-term economic aspects compared to the Sustainable IT gain, technical performance and IT positioning Sustainable from the solution and from the supplier?
strategy.description: A choice of technical base must take into account the technical aspects but also the orientations of the suppliers and the ease of deploying the production carried out from this base while limiting the environmental footprints. The criteria for the selection of this type of component must be clearly defined.

specifications.title: Have the Sustainable IT challenges of the project been communicated to the team from the start ?
specifications.test: How many people are aware/ trained in Sustainable IT in the project team?
specifications.description: The Sustainable IT approach is best taken into account when it is part of a systemic process and when it is presented as a direction to follow for all stakeholders.

specifications.title: Does each entity of the Project team have Sustainable IT skills ?
specifications.test: How many people are aware of and trained in Sustainable IT?
specifications.description: Each of the project steps requires specific knowledge for the Sustainable IT aspects, it is important that all the steps are covered so that the Sustainable IT results are consistent throughout the life of the service. OR each porject's milstone  requires specific knowledge of the Sustainable IT aspects. Thus  the final results are consistent throughout the life of the service.

specifications.title: Are the organization's Sustainable IT referents identified ?
specifications.test: Is there a permanent or dedicated Sustainable IT referent for the project?
specifications.description: Sustainable IT requires a strong knowledge which must be carried by the people who are the best adapted.

specifications.title: What editorial approach is planned to make customers aware of Sustainable IT ?
specifications.test: Is Sustainable IT communication to customers defined?
specifications.description: Communication with users and customers is also a company commitment to reduce its environmental footprint and stand out from the competition by displaying its ambition and its Sustainable IT results.

specifications.title: Are LCA data used in adaption of an existing service ?
specifications.test: Have you made previous LCAs available to the project teams?
specifications.description: LCA analyzes can be carried out on existing services in order to make them more efficient in the event of a redesign or adaptation of an existing service. The Sustainable IT specifications and requirements from previous LCAs must be taken up and adapted if necessary.

specifications.title: Does each stakeholder have the latitude to make decisions that may influence the environmental footprint ?
specifications.test: Is the decision-making circuit and autonomy having a Sustainable IT impact defined for each actor?
specifications.description: The specifications and the USER STORY can evolve over time, these evolutions must systematically take into account the Sustainable IT aspects. Adaptations are most often made in the trades. Environmental impacts must also be able to have this latitude with pre-defined validation paths.

specifications.title: Is the definition of the requirements carried out by consulting the end users ?
specifications.test: Does the project owner contain a witness user or a representative mastering the trade?
specifications.description: When user needs are extrapolated from analyzes and organizational objectives, this can lead to expressions of need that are broader than those that users will actually use and the service will be more consumer than necessary.

specifications.title: Do you transmit a Sustainable IT pedagogy to users ?
specifications.test: Is a witness user with a strong Sustainable IT color included in the project approach?
specifications.description: The uses of services are a source of resource consumption. If users are encouraged and guided to reduce their impact with educational approaches, this makes the entire service more efficient in reducing its impact.

specifications.title: Are the Sustainable IT aspects propagated and maintained across all stakeholders ?
specifications.test: What are the markers and follow-up steps defined?
specifications.description: When each of the players has easy access to markers to assess the environmental footprint of their actions and choices, they can adapt their practices to make the service more efficient and responsible.

specifications.title: Are the target profiles defined ?
specifications.test: Are the Sustainable IT goals qualified for each target profile?
specifications.description: To clearly express the Sustainable IT objectives in each of the specifications, it is essential to locate the target profiles and to associate them with specific Sustainable IT objectives.

specifications.title: Are Sustainable IT aspects propagated and maintained across all user profiles ?
specifications.test: What is your frequency of Sustainable IT communication for each user profile?
specifications.description: The use phases are a way of communicating and maintaining the link on Sustainable IT aspects with users, it is also an approach that offers a different communication channel and stands out from the competition by involving users and making actors of the proposed service.

specifications.title: What proportion of the functionalities (User Story) have a Sustainable IT component ?
specifications.test: Is a Sustainable IT requirement justified rather than a Sustainable IT aspect in a more general requirement?
specifications.description: Some functionalities can be designed with very different Sustainable IT impacts. In the absence of clarification, the chosen solution will most often be driven by ease or technical appetite, which is generally opposed to sustainable IT performance. The only way to guide decisions is to introduce points of attention on Sustainable IT aspects in the majority of User Stories.

specifications.title: Are the Sustainable IT review steps included in the methodology ?
specifications.test: How and who arbitrates conflicts? (for example: Budget and Sustainable IT)
specifications.description: The Sustainable IT objectives must be clearly defined and the project management must treat the monitoring of these objectives with reviews in the same way as the other categories of requirements, by associating the actors able to arbitrate, justify and validate the decisions.

specifications.title: Do any functionalities (User Story) only concern the Sustainable IT aspects ?
specifications.test: What is the objective set at the start of the project?
specifications.description: The project must define Sustainable IT requirements (Non-Functional Requirements - NFR) or specific User Stories that will introduce Sustainable IT orientations into the design. These elements will be taken care of in the same way as the other NFRs (security, accessibility for example) and will guarantee that the Sustainable IT aspects will be taken into account in all stages of the project.

specifications.title: What is the frequency of review / validation of Sustainable IT elements, in a manner similar to "Security" reviews and validation ?
specifications.test: Is the review process formalized?
specifications.description: The taking into account of the Sustainable IT aspects made at the start of the design can be respected but in an iterative mode it is possible to gradually deviate from it. Sustainable IT compliance reviews are essential to maintain the consistency of the project.

specifications.title: Is each feature evaluated against uses ?
specifications.test: Are the functions expected by the user and their scope of action defined in order to provide a framework for interactions and not go into the superfluous?
specifications.description: User Stories / Use Cases must be specified in relation to uses so as not to lead to an inflation of functionalities that would be superfluous in relation to the real needs of users. Offering marginal functionalities will generate an unjustified environmental footprint, cost and misunderstanding of the additional service.

specifications.title: Is the use of continuous integration widespread ?
specifications.test: Is the complexity of the service framed / monitored in the continuous integration process?
specifications.description: From a Sustainable IT point of view, capitalizing on achievements and providing a technical model that guarantees these achievements, avoids anomalies and non-quality additional costs.

specifications.title: Do the continuous integration processes not generate gaps in the consideration of Sustainable IT aspects ?
specifications.test: Does each stage of the life cycle take into account the Sustainable IT aspects?
specifications.description: The different phases of continuous integration make it possible to manage the processes with defined expectations. One of these integration steps must validate compliance with Sustainable IT impacts.

specifications.title: Are non-functional requirements (User Story) treated in the same way for the IT aspects Sustainable, security and accessibility ?
specifications.test: Are the validation mechanisms similar for security and IT Sustainable aspects?
specifications.description: The categories of non-functional requirements (NFR) intervene transversally in project management because dependencies are most often associated with behaviors that can only rarely be linked to a single action. This is also the case with Sustainable IT, an effective one-off decision can be rendered obsolete by upstream or downstream actions.

specifications.title: Is the inventory of the input data made available for reuse in other projects ?
specifications.test: What data is used as input and produced for the other projects?
specifications.description: The Sustainable IT principles are stable and the best practices deployed can be directly used in other project contexts, especially since the projects within an organization have many similarities, whether in methods, objectives or functional perimeters. In the specification phase, collecting, preparing and producing these elements is a guarantee of efficiency and reliability to increase the maturity of the organization in its Sustainable IT practices.

specifications.title: Are the Sustainable IT requirements associated with all product functionalities ?
specifications.test: Is the product validated as necessary in relation to its environmental footprint?
specifications.description: Each feature implemented must take into account Sustainable IT so that the entire service is designed with the most complete respect for Sustainable IT principles, an aspect not covered which may cancel all or part of the benefits acquired elsewhere. . It is more effective to have a balanced treatment on the whole, rather than aiming for excellence in one part and leaving substantial gaps in others.

specifications.title: Is each main or secondary function of the service understood in terms of its importance in the service ?
specifications.test: Are the rules for validating the Sustainable IT impacts of the functions described?
specifications.description: The Sustainable IT consistency pushes to ensure that the secondary functions do not have a greater environmental footprint than the main functions. The specifications must clearly identify the main and secondary functions and their impacts from a Sustainable IT perspective.

specifications.title: Are all the project requirements (performance, security, accessibility, Sustainable IT) associated with each functionality ?
specifications.test: Are the priority rules defined and arbitrated in the event of a conflict?
specifications.description: The complete panorama of non-functional requirements (Security, Accessibility, Sustainable IT) makes it possible to facilitate arbitrations and to determine the axis which will be chosen when elements present conflicts. The conflict is difficult to treat locally, only the global vision will ensure that the balance is respected throughout the project.

specifications.title: Are the cases of exclusion of each functionality addressed and alternatives offered ?
specifications.test: Are the costs and benefits of the alternatives evaluated?
specifications.description: Certain features not retained may nevertheless be of interest and lead to finding replacement alternatives. These intermediate solutions respect the same project processes in terms of Sustainable IT.

specifications.title: Is the need for a feature validated in relation to its Sustainable IT impact ?
specifications.test: Are the trade-offs between Sustainable IT gains and project costs clearly identified?
specifications.description: The selection of the specified functionalities deemed essential may be questioned in its initial form in relation to the Sustainable IT impacts. In this case the costs / benefits will have to take into account these oppositions and be the subject of an adaptation to make converge the 2 approaches: functional necessity and Sustainable IT impact.

specifications.title: What alternatives are proposed to deal with a functionality not retained ?
specifications.test: Does each removed feature have an alternative available, if the feature is useful?
specifications.description: Alternative solutions can be deployed knowing that they are not the most efficient from a Sustainable IT point of view but provide a more efficient first step compared to the solution not including any Sustainable IT consideration. These alternative tracks must be transitory and be subject to review planning in order to gradually increase their Sustainable IT compliance.

specifications.title: Are the guidelines of the service not based on the effects of artificial addiction ?
specifications.test: Is the captology assessment matrix applied?
specifications.description: The over-consumption of the uses of the service implies the creation of a dependence of the user on the service, and artificially increases the load for using the service, and therefore the environmental footprint. These addictive effects are detrimental to the respect of Sustainable IT principles.

specifications.title: Are user and technical interfaces designed to be efficient from an IT Sustainable point of view ?
specifications.test: Is the Sustainable IT cost of the interfaces evaluated?
specifications.description: The link between the user and the service can generate complex, long journeys, with very high input volumes or information presented. If the management of interfaces is efficient for the user, it will most often be just as efficient from an IT point of view.

specifications.title: Are the regulatory aspects of accessibility taken into account ?
specifications.test: Is compliance with the RGAA guaranteed?
specifications.description: Failure to comply with regulations is first of all illegal and can lead to significant penalties. It also cuts off users, even outside the scope of disability, from access to the service.

specifications.title: Is the service GDPR compliant ?
specifications.test: Are the GDPR documents for the project produced and validated by the DPO?
specifications.description: During specifications, if new data collections are planned, they must systematically be evaluated for personal data, be associated with the processing register and the PIA, in conjunction with the DPO. Aspects of trust and respect for users is one of the dimensions of Sustainable IT.

specifications.title: Is the security appropriate for the value of my data ?
specifications.test: Are safety rules associated with regular audits?
specifications.description: Securing data often requires redundant elements, backup and duplication methods that generate an additional environmental footprint. Certain categories of data fully justify these provisions, but for others the extreme security does not make sense, except the ease of treating all information in the same way. The level of security, from the moment it presents an additional environmental cost, must be related to the data.

specifications.title: Are the technical solutions adopted driven by use rather than technical interest ?
specifications.test: Do all the technologies used have a validated and shared justification?
specifications.description: Technical functions often need to express their skills and their monitoring of technological advances by choosing the most recent solutions defined in their ecosystem as the most advanced. This pushes to make implementation choices guided by technological appeal rather than by efficiency, in particular Sustainable IT. Reorienting technical practices on Sustainable IT challenges is a good practice to maintain the technical interest of professionals and allow them to progress with concrete results.

specifications.title: Is the functional value assessment of each user interaction performed ?
specifications.test: Is the functionality essential?
specifications.description: Each time the user interacts with the service, a large number of "invisible" mechanisms are triggered. Each of these, while executing, consumes resources. To reduce this consumption, in addition to the principles of optimization of algorithms, it is more useful and often easier to limit the number of these interactions.

specifications.title: Can the impact of the coverage of the functionality be reduced by the technical solution envisaged ?
specifications.test: Have the alternative technologies been tested?
specifications.description: Some functionalities are natively offered by technical components, but these components are very rarely limited to the only desired scope and provide many other functionalities which may not be useful. The fact of being able to reduce a technical component to only really useful inputs is an important Sustainable IT benefit.

specifications.title: In the purchasing process (Call for tenders) are Sustainable IT commitment requirements asked of external service providers ?
specifications.test: Are service providers' sustainable IT requirements defined?
specifications.description: A project is rarely carried out with a perimeter covered at 100% within the organization, a number of external resources are mobilized during the project. The specifications make it possible to identify these necessary resources and associate them with Sustainable IT requirements to allow the selection of service providers according to technical constraints, economic solvency and sustainable IT.

specifications.title: Do all specified data and procedures have end-of-life information ?
specifications.test: Is the catalog of procedures and data up to date?
specifications.description: The specifications reveal data collections of asynchronous procedures or periodic tasks essential for the proper functioning of the service. These elements are most often invisible and in the absence of explicit specifications of the withdrawal process they are rarely taken into account for the purposes of operating a service. Each of these elements must carry its own end-of-life information.

specifications.title: Are the load, benefits, risks followed ?
specifications.test: Is a retrospective planned to assess the environmental gains?
specifications.description: The putting into production of a service respecting the Sustainable IT principles is an important asset for an organization. For all stakeholders, the assessment of the conduct of the project and the handling of Sustainable IT issues is an additional means of capitalizing on the benefits of the operation and of calmly assessing the risks and load taken into account in the project. project in order to facilitate the taking into account of Sustainable IT in future projects.

specifications.title: Is a risk monitoring plan deployed ?
specifications.test: Does the risk monitoring plan include Sustainable IT?
specifications.description: Certain technical choices are oriented by the Sustainable IT angle, and technical adaptations are made for more Sustainable IT compliance. This can introduce additional risks (delays, difficulties, anomalies). These risks must be monitored and the risk treatment plan must take into account these elements associated with Sustainable IT choices.

specifications.title: Is a gain in notoriety and capitalization associated with the Sustainable IT aspects of the project ?
specifications.test: Are non-financial benefits valued?
specifications.description: The conduct of a Sustainable IT project has an impact beyond the technical and business spheres of the project, which can allow the organization to display a strong affinity with environmental constraints which can be exploited in institutional or informal communications operations. These elements can be quantified in the project budgets.

specifications.title: Do secondary functions also have a lower impact on the environmental footprint ?
specifications.test: Are the environmental footprints of each feature assessed against the nature and importance of the feature?
specifications.description: 80% of uses are handled by 20% of functionalities. Without being an immutable rule, it is very often the case. We must not fall into the trap where the 20% of marginal uses consume 80% of the environmental footprints of the project.

specifications.title: Have you identified performance indicators for life cycle monitoring ?
specifications.test: What indicators are in place, and how are the data on which these indicators are based made reliable?
specifications.description: Universal IT Sustainable Indicators are not really available, which can lead to spending a lot of energy and resources on defining the best indicators. This represents an overload in the project which can lead to questioning the treatment of Sustainable IT impacts in the projects. It would be a shame if the credibility of Sustainable IT benefits were degraded by the search for measurement points. The reliability of an indicator is dictated by the reliability of the data used to calculate it, it is better to start with indicators that are undoubtedly less ambitious but fair and inexpensive in terms of project load.

specifications.title: Is the management of the impacts of software updates on the obsolescence of equipment assessed ?
specifications.test: Are the impacts on the hardware components of the software updates traced?
specifications.description: In iterative development and throughout the life of the service updates will be applied. Each of these adaptations must make it possible to continue using current equipment and not add artificial constraints which would lead to saturating the processing capacities of user terminals, nor introduce a technical update which would generate incompatibility, would require / would lead to a renewal. equipment.

specifications.title: Is current user equipment assessed ?
specifications.test: Is the valid user equipment range available?
specifications.description: The specifications must define the ranges of terminals that the service must support so that users with older devices can access the service under the best conditions. Hardware incompatibilities are a source of wishes / imperatives to renew terminals before they are really out of use. Sustainable IT helps extend the life of equipment.

specifications.title: Do the project reviews take into account the validations of Sustainable IT requirements ?
specifications.test: Is the conflict arbitration process shared by all stakeholders?
specifications.description: The scoping and the specification phase provide for intermediate deliveries, in the form of POC, MVP, BETA. Each of these interim deliveries is an opportunity to review and validate the coverage of Sustainable IT requirements.

specifications.title: During each new production launch, is a review of compliance with Sustainable IT issues carried out ?
specifications.test: Are journal anomalies logged and reused?
specifications.description: Going into production should not be considered the final stage in the life of a project in compliance with Sustainable IT principles. This go-live operation makes it possible to rule on the Sustainable IT commitments defined and fulfilled during the project and to validate that these elements will be monitored throughout the active phase of the service, and taken into account when the service is withdrawn at the end of its life. .

specifications.title: Does the target product have a fixed shelf life ?
specifications.test: Does the product have an "expiration date"?
specifications.description: The services respond to an opportunity and are created to process that request. In a very changing and unpredictable technical and economic environment, they rarely have an infinite life expectancy. It is useful from a Sustainable IT point of view to decide beforehand on the term of operation of the service to avoid that it does not exist ad vitam aeternam when the object of the service no longer exists.

specifications.title: Are solution providers and service providers selected on the basis of their ability to meet Sustainable IT specifications ?
specifications.test: Are suppliers' Sustainable IT indicators taken into account when selecting service providers?
specifications.description: The specifications highlight needs for outsourced services or relationships with service providers. In the selection rules for suppliers of external services or products, the Sustainable IT aspects must be taken into account in the same way as if the service or product were supported internally. The specifications must set out, in addition to technical, budgetary and security standards considerations, the Sustainable IT principles that the supplier must fulfill.

specifications.title: Are the physical travel aspects evaluated during the selection of service providers, technical solutions and the organization of internal actors involved in the project ?
specifications.test: What physical travel budget is allocated to the project?
specifications.description: The environmental footprint of physical movements is very visible and easily estimated. When interacting with partners, the distance, the number of trips must be evaluated and restricted. Defining a travel budget for the entire project can bring more control over this aspect and promote, whenever possible, distancing rather than face-to-face points.

specifications.title: Do all providers' stakeholders have the same social benefits and working conditions ?
specifications.test: Does the service provider use human resources outside the national territory or with specific contracts?
specifications.description: In the Sustainable IT dimensions, human and economic aspects occupy an important place. Ensuring that all stakeholders including service providers (and its own subcontractors and suppliers) used for the project have the same socio-economic frameworks is necessary so that the coherence of Sustainable IT efforts is not destroyed by a choice that could have been avoided.

specifications.title: Are the workstations subject to lifecycle management ?
specifications.test: Are the development and integration / test workstations chosen and monitored with regard to their environmental footprints?
specifications.description: Each of the internal players will mobilize technical equipment to manage and develop the project. The workstations of the whole team are a relatively simple point to address from a Sustainable IT point of view. With the monitoring of the life cycle of the equipment, the use of materials with environmental labels, the control of the electrical power supplies of the workstation according to the presence / absence of the workstation.

specifications.title: Has a common space been made available to the project for sharing resources ?
specifications.test: Do the working documents only exist in a single copy shared by all concerned?
specifications.description: During project monitoring, many documents are produced, reviewed and validated. Duplication of documents, transfers to multiple recipients is a source of excessive consumption of resources. Most often, the use of a shared space with the implementation of access rules makes it possible to avoid these environmental footprints.

specifications.title: Do the resources / components available for the project have information regarding Sustainable IT compliance ?
specifications.test: Does each component developed have a Sustainable IT impact score?
specifications.description: Modular developments are implemented in projects to facilitate reuse and allow the assembly of validated components, which translates into efficiency and reliability gains. This practice is based on the descriptions of the interfaces (input-output) of these components, their frameworks of use and their dependencies. In addition to these technical elements the Sustainable IT aspects and benefits implemented in the component are useful to capitalize in addition to the technical aspects on the Sustainable IT aspects.

specifications.title: In the technical resources of the project, are dependency management taken into account, to limit the obesity of the technical solutions employed ?
specifications.test: Is a component dependency tracking tool used?
specifications.description: Most projects are a suite of component integration with specific interface developments between these components. Very often components from public libraries (open source or commercial) provide a set of functionalities which are only rarely all used and drain dependencies on other components with the same characteristics. In the end, the project aggregates a large volume of the library while a small part is actually used. Favoring components whose dependencies and functionalities are controllable in relation to the needs is efficient from the sustainable IT point of view.

specifications.title: In the design choices (functional and technical), does the creation, update or end of life of one digital service domain have a reduced impact on other digital service domains ?
specifications.test: Is the publication of interfaces between components systematic?
specifications.description: Project specifications can build on elements already used for other services. These dependencies between services are efficient from a project management point of view but can be penalizing when they impose the maintenance of shared components less efficient from an IT point of view Sustainable, especially when the services using these resources are intended to be arrested at different times.

specifications.title: Are the implementation of new services under regulatory constraints (health, banking, etc.) necessary and, if necessary, do they rely on an available service base ?
specifications.test: How much regulated data (health, banking, etc.) are needed?
specifications.description: The practice of professionals using regulated data is guided by data security and by reducing the impact of using the service to stay focused on the main issue. The specifications must take these elements into account and reuse as many elements as usual from these types of consolidated services in the form of a service base.

specifications.title: What are the defined KPIs ?
specifications.test: Are the ranges of values ​​for the KPIs defined?
specifications.description: Businesses and management are used to steering the activity with a range of business indicators. Monitoring Sustainable IT performance will also require dedicated indicators to monitor the impacts. For the determination of the indicators, ranges of performance values ​​must be defined iteratively and follow the increase in maturity of the organization in the apprehension of these data so that the decision-making processes can be put in place to carry out a management of Sustainable IT aspects.

uxui.title: In the brain storming process, are all stakeholders taken into account in their entire (human) dimension ?
uxui.test:
Has stakeholder mapping been carried out?

Is stakeholder prioritization done?
uxui.description: Putting the User at the center of the reflection is the guarantee to cover the essential needs of your targets and to move in the right direction. By Users, we mean not only the end users of the service or product but also the various stakeholders of the project. Taking into consideration  your users with a human and empathetic dimension allows you to enlarge  yourcogitation and go beyond the economic and technological aspects of the project.

uxui.title: Is the planet taken into account in the brain storming process, in order  to integrate the ecological dimension (planet centric design) ?
uxui.test: Is the planet centric toolkit known and used?
uxui.description: Every design decision has an impact. If environmental and ecological issues are not at the heart of the analysis, no objective of controlling or reducing impacts will be taken into account and therefore respected.

uxui.title: Are the extra-financial added value of sustainble digital technology valued in the business model ?
uxui.test: Are human, ecological and economic values ​​included in the business model canvas and are they approved by all stakeholders?
uxui.description: Responsible Digital (Sustainable IT) can be considered as a real source of economic development within your organization. Integrating the Sustainable IT dimension into your business model on a long-term basis will allow you to avoid constant arbitrations on its importance  and its integration into your future projects.

uxui.title: Is a sustainable IT process planned at the level of project governance ?
uxui.test:
Are reviews and cross-functional monitoring of Sustainable IT aspects set up?
How often are Sustainable IT reviews scheduled?
uxui.description: A Sustainable IT approach must be systemic, over the entire life cycle of the project, and therefore supported by all development actors.

uxui.title: Are Sustainable IT improvements identified and systematically planned ?
uxui.test: Has the project review been carried out and does it improve the impacts on the 3ps?
uxui.description: The aim of continual improvement allows to increase the performance of the project and therefore to limit its impact.
uxui.score: Number of sust. IT items / Number of improvement

uxui.title: For the Sustainable IT aspects, do the project managers (project manager, product owner, etc.) have the same prerogatives as the business aspects ?
uxui.test: What is the  the project's manager decision level for the Sustainable IT aspects?
uxui.description: For the Sustainable IT issue to be followed, it must be personified by an identified, responsible person who disseminates the issues to each business stakeholder and takes part in decisions. This role can be defined in his personal objectives or job description.

uxui.title: Is the deliverables's output (documentary production included) used upstream of the project and is it produced to allow it to be reused in subsequent projects ?
uxui.test: Is the quality approach applied to all the communication features of the product?
uxui.description: A Sustainable IT knowledge and skills base will emerge as the projects progress. It is important to capitalize on the experience acquired and to disseminate good practices. This will allow your teams to develop instinctive reations  and reuse proven solutions on future projects.

uxui.title: Is a budget on the 3Ps axes associated and monitored during the project ?
uxui.test:
Are UX-UI missions related to Sustainable IT clearly describied and communicated in the budget?
Are indicators including the 3Ps put in place to monitor the project budget?
uxui.description: Depending on the organization's level of maturity, taking into account of Sustainable IT can generate a cost and a time of reflection which must be foreseen and associated with the expected benefits. The posts and time allocated to Sustainable IT on the budget must be approved, obvious and communicated precisely to all project stakeholders.

uxui.title: Are stakeholders informed about Sustainable IT ?
uxui.test: Is knowledge sharing and awareness raising among stakeholders in place?
uxui.description: To accede, you have to understand. Sustainable IT is not a technical discipline. The principles of Sustainable IT must be implemented in business practices and the behavior of each of the particiants. All project stakeholders must be made aware of Sustainable IT in order to act at their level.
uxui.score: Number of sust. IT awareness / Number of team members

uxui.title: Are the different phases of the project identified with their validation process, in order to get stakeholders to adhere to the iterative process ?
uxui.test: How are the project stages for Sustainable IT approved?
uxui.description: The Sustainable IT approach is iterative and perfectly suited to Agile processes, which also imposes efficient and formalized control and validation mechanisms.

uxui.title: Have you set up an environmental footprint monitoring reporting system, resulting from the service's utilization and explotation by every user ?
uxui.test: Is an ecological meter offered to the user in a didactic way?
uxui.description: User engagement will encourage yielding to the Sustainable IT approach, which is an important aspect of promoting the values ​​and results of the organization. Communicating highly visual elements to users makes it easier for them to participate in and understand your commitments.

uxui.title: What data is available for communication involving compliance with Sustainable IT standards and recommendations on the service ?
uxui.test: Are the labels and badges to be attained by the application defined at the start of the project and displayed in the service?
uxui.description: A number of resources are available to display the level of completion and involvement in Sustainable IT. This results in badges, labels, standards ... allowing the user to identify the organizations that are making the most considerable efforts on social and environmental issues.

uxui.title: In order to encourage users to be protagonist in reducing their impacts, do they have access to references that introduce Sustainable IT practices ?
uxui.test: Are eco-tips and usage data accessible to the user while using the service?
uxui.description: User's posture remains one of the points over which the organization has no control. Despite all the expected benefits of a responsible design of digital services, user's  practice can either multiply the positive effects or reduce them significantly. Communicating elements that make the user aware of these actions so that they can reduce their impact is essential.

uxui.title: Is a policy for compatibility with obsolete terminals and software versions established ?
uxui.test:
Is the list of terminals extended to secondary target terminals?

Are there any particular requirements in terms of user experience (habits at an existing interface, at a given terminal)?
uxui.description: Technological advances are increase constantly  hardware requirements, reducing the devices's number on which a service can run. This aspect excludes certain users and encourages the renewal of equipment still in perfect working condition with the associated environmental footprint.

uxui.title: Are the obstacles to the use of digital technology (accessibility, technical, territorial) taken into account ?
uxui.test:
Does the personas' profiles take into account all cases of digital inclusion?

Are users in difficulty spotted with the persona's help and supported throughout the service's life cycle through user tests or onboarding training?
uxui.description: In order to be responsible, digital technology must first and foremost be available and accessible (In France, 14% of the population has no internet access or no digital skills (source: Vie-publique.fr / DILA Source: ICT Surveys - INSEE), in France more than one user out of 3 lacks basic digital skills. This is the purpose of the human dimension of Sustainable IT, which treats the difficulties of using  digital technology for certain population according to their ability to understand the elements (accessibility) and access and quality of networks.

uxui.title: What solutions have been deployed to fight against electronicism and simplify uses and services ?
uxui.test: Is the learning curve of using and understanding the service taken care of?
uxui.description: Diminishing inequalities of access to digital service so as not to exclude any user, these exclusion cases can be greatly reduced by taking social, generational and territorial disparities into account very early in the design.

uxui.title: Are the technological, social, physical and temporal criteria that allow your users to reach their aim  and limit the digital gap taken into account ?
uxui.test: Are users in difficulty in using the service properly taken into account and represented, as well as their issues, via objective tools (personas, spinning mills, question scales, interviews, narrative universes, etc.)?
uxui.description: Dealing with cases of digital exclusion is the first essential step, but this does not guarantee that the user will be able to achieve their goals easily by using the service. These aspects must be addressed by facilitating the user's journey.

uxui.title: Does the service work with weak connections ?
uxui.test: Is a so-called "Low" mode feasible?
uxui.description: Development and testing environments are often efficient, which hides the networks with poor performance impact. In order not not to make the service unusable in conditions where network speeds are reduced, the Sustainable IT approach must take into account an adapted design to territories or locations where poor network access.

uxui.title: Are the assistance service access mechanisms available and suitable for all audiences ?
uxui.test: Have the patterns of access to assistance been tested with the concerned groups, have any difficulties been detected?
uxui.description: The interaction aptitude between the user and the service can be improved with online support process that must meet the same Sustainable IT requirements as the whole service. Accessibility must be thought of for the service as well as for the help solutions.

uxui.title: Has a human fall-back been prepared to backup the service's utilization ?
uxui.test: After how many unsuccessful attempts is the user put in touch with a human operator?
uxui.description: The task of user assistance is most often delegated to a PLC, in order to provide quick answers and avoid waiting times for frequently asked answers. Dealing with a PLC can be frustrating , therefore humain contact assitance must be avaliable,  without neglegting the Sustainable IT criteria.

uxui.title: In the definition of personae, have the target versions of devices, OS and browsers been taken into account ?
uxui.test: What maximum compatibility date is defined, making it possible to determine the technical elements of obsolescence of the targets' IT equipment?
uxui.description: The business line, the user's profile allows most often to qualify the equipment park that will be used for the service. The materials are determined by their technical capacities (computing power, memory, network capacity, sensors, size and screen quality) but also by the operating systems they can accommodate. Each constraint that the service imposes reduces the number of stations that will be able to use it and therefore excludes a group of users.

uxui.title: From the design stage, does the service meet the current accessibility standards in  (at a minimum) ?
uxui.test: What is the intended and measured level of accessibility?
uxui.description: Beyond the strictly legal aspects, anticipation of taking accessibility into account is necessary to ensure coverage of this subject throughout the service life. Anticipating future points of regulations and standards allows  to perpetuate the service by limiting the need for updates dictated by the legal environment.

uxui.title: Can any type of user easily know where he is in the service, by setting up an inclusive navigation system ?
uxui.test: Is a navigation marker (breadcrumb or equivalent) present?
uxui.description: The more user-friendly and well-built the service, the less time the user will spend finding the information they are looking for, which will reduce parasitic browsing and reduce the consumption of resources and energy.

uxui.title: Is a visual soberness implemented so as  to reduce energy resources use and the impact on the material deterioration of the visual, sound and tactile interface's components ?
uxui.test:
Is the graphic charter eco-compatible?
Does the graphic charter respect accessibility standards?
uxui.description: Visual, sound and tactile elements / components can prioritized a purely aesthetic and / or marketing approach but have very little interest for the user. The simplification of these elements will bring better ergonomics and a use adapted to each one as well as a reduction of the energy impact.

uxui.title: Are the features used by the user ?
uxui.test: Are the proposed features expected and used by your main users and do they bring real value to your product?
uxui.description:
According to studies (software cast and standish group), 70% of the features are never or hardly used. (ref 115 best practices)

The number of functionalities available in a digital service directly impact the consumption of resources and the environmental footprint, by creating functionalities of little use. These are totally unnecessary sources of environmental debt. The functionalities also increase the volume of the service, which introduces loading delays and additional storage spaces.

uxui.title: Are decision-making justified and approved by reliable indicators on the use of functionalities throughout the service life cycle ?
uxui.test: What data is collected, how often?
uxui.description: Monitoring of uses allows to validate the estimations made at the beginning of the design and identify areas for improvement. But this principle is based on reliable data sources.

uxui.title: Is there a policy / approach / routine for the progressive reduction and prioritization of functionalities, interactions and graphic elements ?
uxui.test: Is there a tracking tool to prioritize, and evaluate the functionalities' use throughout the  service life cyle?
uxui.description: The deletions of elements on interfaces may not disrupt users, and therefore generate a reduced footprint with fewer elements and functionality without degrading the value of the service while limiting its environmental footprint.

uxui.title: Are the stakeholders of the SEO service involved, starting  from the design phase ?
uxui.test: Are SEO feedbacks taken into account in the design phase to improve Sustainable IT impacts?
uxui.description: Algorithms' optimization  tend to accumulate data, in the majority of cases the data collected is not analyzed and therefore is not employed to rationalize uses. Optimizations must be part of  an iterative process and each feedback must allow a measured gain in efficiency before moving on to the next step.

uxui.title: Is the practice of e-mailing considered, justified and reduced to what is strictly necessary ?
uxui.test: Is access to unsubscribe fast and easy for the user (without a confirmation request)?
uxui.description: Emailing  especially when the emails contain rich content, generate a significant environmental footprint. In the case of mass distribution, these impacts are multiplied. Newsletters  for exemple is generate explosion of traffic. The content, volumes and delivery targets must be reduced to compensate with efficiency and relevance for what was supported by mass delivery.
uxui.score: Number of removed content / Number of unused content

uxui.title: Are an archiving schedule and a lighter version of the old searchable content implemented ?
uxui.test: Are the archiving criteria and the schedule defined?
uxui.description:
Often, a significant amount of files, often versioned, are produced to meet customer requirements.
Establishing a good file management practice (customer and internal deliverables) is essential.
Sorting and deleting obsolete and unusable versions will have a positive impact on storage.
Indeed, all this stored data has an environmental cost because it is linked to the use of servers most often, and therefore represents a significant financial cost.
Defining a content archiving policy will contribute to responsible and efficient management of the production of the service.

uxui.title: Has the analytics been limited to what is strictly necessary to optimize the service ?
uxui.test: Is the use of analytics optimized as necessary?
uxui.description: The analytics data collect is installed in the source codes and must be positioned only at the points where they bring a possibility of performance improvement because their actions are not neutral; they collect, transmit, store data and burden the services by adding executable codes that require processing resources on the user device, on networks and on remote servers. In addition, the data collected may be transmitted and used by other persons for purposes of which the user is not always aware.

uxui.title: Are third-party services (social network feeds, social wall, carousels, google maps, etc.) not used for convenience to compensate for the lack of content production resources ?
uxui.test: Has an alternative to third-party services been considered, is it possible?
uxui.description:
It is common to use third-party services related to the use of social networks, geolocation, etc.
The use of these third-party services must be at the service of information and not replace it because their use is very resource-intensive, bandwidth and battery of terminals in particular.
It is important to limit their use to what is strictly necessary in order to limit their environmental footprint.

uxui.title: Does the  service's use make it possible to consider software or hardware configurations that have less impact on the environment ?
uxui.test: In the user research, have any technical, material or human constraints that would require an adapted version of the service been identified?
uxui.description:
User's equipement is increasingly more efficient and digital services utilize these technical capacities.
This emphasizes the digital gap by excluding some of the users who cannot afford these expensive terminals. 

It is therefore important to question the usefulness of using these technologies to achieve the finality of digital service while allowing  access to a majority.

uxui.title: Does the user experience take into account possible changes to the service (adding / removing features) ?
uxui.test: Have future service evolution needs been identified and planned?
uxui.description:
