architecture.title: Can each component be tested for "Non-Regression" at the functional level ?
architecture.test: Do acceptance tests exist? Are they applied based on  a "test driven development" approach?
architecture.description: Functional tests and test cases allow to increase the reliability of developments and to avoid inefficient software operations that require multiple updates and consume resources without providing needed functionality. In addition to user dissatisfaction, development teams are also frustrated because they have to deal with poor quality without being able to progress in their jobs.

architecture.title: Is a BDD (Behavior Driven Development) approach implemented to steer production through usage ?
architecture.test: Are BDD scenarios available for all features?
architecture.description: The identified and approved use cases allow to limit the developments to concrete cases expected by the users. Their should be in line with real uses, and not be extrapolated from the interpretations of the technical teams.

architecture.title: Does automation of compilation, test, integration, and deployment tasks exist in the continuous integration workflow ?
architecture.test: Existence of a DevOps pipeline?
architecture.description: The reliability of the production process reduces the impact of re-deliveries due to errors and allows the delivery of codes that fulfill their functions. The consumption of resources for an erroneous result is considered an unnecessary waste of resources.

architecture.title: Are the environments other than production (DEV, QA, ...) switched off or decommissioned outside the ranges of use (at night, outside the test periods) ?
architecture.test: Does the infrastructure / application turn off the environments which are not needed to be up all the time?
architecture.description: Apart from production, which may have a 24/7 availability requirement, other environments (tests, integration, acceptance) are most often linked to human operations subject to restricted time slots, or even to limited periods. When the environments are not in use, they should be inactive in order to reduce the energy consumption of these configurations. They should be decommissioned when no further use is planned over a long period.

architecture.title: Are methods in place to measure the actual consumption of the code in production and allow accurate sizing ?
architecture.test: Has the disk consumption been the subject of a dimensioning and an estimate during the DAT phases?
architecture.description: In the absence of reliable metrics, the sizing of physical components is based on estimates that may not be adapted to real use cases. These metrics should be applied according to the following two principles: adjusting the sizing, and identifying overconsumption, which should be then systematically reviewed and addressed.

architecture.title: Is the hosting of applications densified ?
architecture.test: Is the VM over-provisioning rate monitored?
architecture.description: The adaptation of technical resources and their uses must be monitored in relation to the sum of the virtual resources allocated and consumed by the applications. Certain technologies (Virtualization) allow the allocation of several virtual components on the same physical component in order to increase the density of the hosting solutions.

architecture.title: Are unused production environments outside of peak loads turned off or decommissioned ?
architecture.test: Are shutdown/activation thresholds defined and tracked?
architecture.description: Service securitizations allow implementing load distribution solutions. Environments are sized according to the estimated peaks of use, which are most often on a seasonal basis. While remaining active, the replications of servers take loads, however often a smaller environment would be perfectly capable of handling all the traffic. The smaller the number of server instances, the smaller the environmental impact. Since bringing a replica back online is a simple and perfectly controlled operation, there is no benefit to maintaining server images 11 months a year, if the peak load is really only present for 1 month.

architecture.title: Are the definitions of SLA and QoS for each of the functions of the application architecture specified in accordance with the business uses ?
architecture.test: Are there different SLA families for technical architecture elements?
architecture.description: The state of the art technology tends to make all components equally reliable and to strive for excellence in the areas of availability and quality of service. In some cases or for certain functionalities, business needs could be satisfied with lighter constraints. When business and usage are not considered, IT tends to exceed expectations so as not to underperform and not to be put under scrutiny.

architecture.title: Is the digital service efficient all along its lifespan ?
architecture.test: Does the service provide bug fixing updates all along its lifespan?
architecture.description: Technical improvements and bug fixing are frequent during lifespan of a service. The latter must stay up and usable without any heavy device upgrade.

architecture.title: Have the legal constraints related to data preservation been analyzed and the rules and deadlines for "forgetting it" been specified ?
architecture.test:
Are there mechanisms in place for data lifecycle management (expiration)?
Have mechanisms been put in place for archiving data with a low manipulation rate?
Has an end of life for the data been planned (implementation of a validity date for each piece of data, implementation of a validity date by type of technical data, implementation of a validation date by type of functional data)?
Have users been consulted to consider the necessary lifespan of key data?
architecture.description: The regulations impose control of the data life cycle for certain categories (personal data governed by the GDPR), however, the other categories of data are not taken into account, which leads to the accumulation of data without taking into account their expiration dates. This introduces a permanent increase in the volume of data, the volume of backups, and the resources consumed to access the data. As time goes by, the level of accuracy of the data loses its importance, which should lead to a reduction in the volume of data in the phase preceding their removal.

architecture.title: Does the storage strategy keep infrastructure or data duplication to a minimum in relation to its criticality ?
architecture.test: Does the infrastructure minimize the necessary disk volumes (eg: deduplication, compression, ...)?
architecture.description: The energy consumption of the storage system depends on the volume of data, on the space required on physical devices, on the ressources needed to handle the data, on the backup processes and on the security and replication systems. Any positive action taken on one of these aspects can reduce the environmental impact of the data.

architecture.title: Is non-production data anonymized and scaled down to a representative sample of production ?
architecture.test: Has the data that will allow to test and develop each of the features been identified?
architecture.description: The precision and conciseness of the test set data allows to reduce the impacts of the development, test / Q&A phases. It also allows to validate the definition and coverage of test cases which contributes to the final quality of the software. The test data is visible, manipulated outside the security constraints of production, and is therefore less well protected. It should not be a source of information leakage that could be detrimental to the actual users of the service.

architecture.title: Is the frequency of data refresh determined in relation to user expectations ?
architecture.test: What is the minimum level of refresh required by my system?
architecture.description: Updating complex data in real time involves heavy processes, and these operations should be adapted to the users' needs. If they can be deferred to times of lower load, the consumption of technical resources will be reduced.

architecture.title: Are the responsibilities from a GDPR point of view (or local framework in other countries: Privacy Act for example) with service providers clearly defined ?
architecture.test: Is the list of service providers and the modes of intervention and responsibility for the data formalized and monitored?
architecture.description: The regulations require a confirmed knowledge of all service providers in contact with personal data. Data outside the GDPR framework is not subject to this tracking. The data essential to the functioning of a digital service are all important from a human or business point of view. The GDPR practice is proven for a category of data, the generalization of the principle to all data makes it possible to increase the consistency of treatment of all the assets of an organization

architecture.title: Is a model linking CPU/RAM/disk resources and physical indicators (power consumption, water, ...) used ?
architecture.test: Are these indicators communicated and understood (training)?
architecture.description: Each physical element generates an impact, be it energy or the consumption of natural resources. Some indicators are already established and should serve as a basis for impact assessment.

architecture.title: Are all technical components evaluated according to eco-responsible criteria ?
architecture.test: Is each offer evaluated according to criteria (see previous model)

architecture.title: Have digital services' impact measurements been put in place on the service ?
architecture.test: What indicators are analyzed?
architecture.description: Each physical or software element generates an impact, be it energy or the consumption of natural resources. Some indicators are already established and should serve as a basis for impact assessment.

architecture.title: What data is consolidated to establish environmental performance ?
architecture.test: Have the data sources been validated?
architecture.description: The reliability and relevance of the indicators depend on the validity of the input data. It is important to ensure this validity before starting to use environmental performance data.

architecture.title: How efficient is my exchange protocol between content and container ?
architecture.test: Is the data compressed before passing through the network?
architecture.description: The distribution of processing on different and remote hardware imposes transfer mechanisms which can be both frequent and bulky. The environmental gains on these points can be processed by reducing the volume of data exchanged. Data compressions require computational resources which can make these operations inefficient or penalizing.

architecture.title: Are the communication protocols implemented evaluated in relation to the headers / payload data ratio ?
architecture.test: Is there a less verbose exchange protocol?
architecture.description: Environmental gains on distributed architectures can be addressed by having an efficient relationship between the encapsulation data of the exchange protocol and the "payload": payload. The encapsulations of the protocols require computational resources which can introduce a significant additional cost.

architecture.title: Is the chosen communication protocol located in the ascending, stable or descending phase of its use in relation to performance, security, legal obligations ?
architecture.test: Is the exchange protocol proprietary or open source?
architecture.description: Technological advances increasingly take into account the Sustainable IT aspects. The more advanced the technical project providing the communication protocols, the more chance there will be that the environmental aspects are integrated natively.

architecture.title: Are grid alternatives assessed against energy consumption ?
architecture.test: Is the network used mainly the least energy consuming, among the existing solutions so as not to have to add new infrastructures?
architecture.description: The ARCEP report (October 2019 - The digital carbon footprint) classifies GHG consumption by type of network. Wired or fiber networks are at least 3 times more energy efficient than wireless networks. 4G is one of the most energy intensive consumers. On wireless networks, consumption is very closely linked to the volume of data, which is less true on wired networks. From another point of view the electronic components of the "wireless" are less robust and can involve more need of renewal. Since these components are usually integrated on the motherboards of the peripherals, the failure usually requires the replacement of the entire device.

architecture.title: Is the ability of my system to operate despite connection difficulties specified and accepted by the business lines ?
architecture.test: Has an offline mode been planned?
architecture.description: Unequal access to networks is an important factor which keeps part of the population from using digital services.

architecture.title: Does an asynchronous communication system exist ?
architecture.test: Are exchanges that do not require an immediate response done asynchronously?
architecture.description: The introduction of processing times, especially in the case of poor network coverage, pushes some users away.

architecture.title: Is the architecture modular ?
architecture.test: Are the application's functionalities broken down into independent bricks with input / output standardization allowing their individual replacement?
architecture.description: The efforts to adapt to environmental constraints made and stabilized must be able to benefit all of the organization's projects. Capitalizing on the best practices deployed is a guarantee of environmental and operational efficiency. The modular concept also makes it possible to rapidly propagate all the environmental benefits that could be integrated into a component, within the framework of monitoring the state of the art and environmental performance.

architecture.title: Is the architecture granular and are the interfaces consistent to respect the independence of each entity ?
architecture.test: Have the functionalities of the application been classified in order to define the essentiality of certain functionalities with regard to other functionalities which are just as important but not considered to be vital to the system?
architecture.description: The ability to carry out assemblies allowing to cover all the functionalities by using elements which have already been the subject of adaptations to reduce the impacts from a Sustainable IT point of view is an effective solution.

architecture.title: Is the capacity of my network to adapt over time the subject of a specific study ?
architecture.test: Does my architecture allow the technology of one layer to be replaced by another?
architecture.description: Technical advances and progress in energy consumption of networks must be able to be quickly implemented without generating a major overhaul of the software design of the service.

architecture.title: Is a cache in place between the different components of the IS to limit exchanges on the network, when the nature of the data allows it ?
architecture.test: Is the label translation data cached locally?
architecture.description: The reduction of the volumes of exchanges, of operations of calculations, processing, and access to data is an axis of optimization of the consumption of resources. The implementation of caching systems reduces the costs of repetitive operations. Cache mechanisms can be deployed at different waypoints in a service. The closer the cache is to the requestor that it is to serve, the smaller the volume of data in transit and the length of the path taken by the data. The closer the cache is to the data source, the more it can be shared by a large number of users, but the data will still be exchanged, only the processing and collection operations will be reduced.

architecture.title: Does the choice of suppliers take into account Responsible Digital and CSR aspects in the same way as the solvency data ?
architecture.test: What are the requested indicators and the acceptability thresholds?
architecture.description: The qualification of suppliers is based on decision rules which make it possible to decide on the sustainability of the relationship. These rules must include elements related to Sustainable IT. These Sustainable IT aspects must have a significant impact in the assessment of the supplier's solvency.

architecture.title: Is each component deployed qualified from the point of view of its lifespan, and are the deprovisioning procedures systematically expressed ?
architecture.test: What lifespan is associated with each component?
architecture.description: All the resources of a component must be managed and a lifetime, a withdrawal process must be in place. These elements must also take into account recurring processing (batch, CRON, etc.), data and backups. Maintaining or forgetting inactive components on production systems is both a waste of resources, but also a weakness in security.

architecture.title: Has data frugality been incorporated ?
architecture.test: What is the level of compliance with the NF and mainly the 2NF?
architecture.description: Reducing volume, especially data, reduces the impact from a Sustainable IT perspective

architecture.title: Does the application minimize the data to be exchanged with other applications or users with the use of a flow matrix ?
architecture.test: Does the application need to exchange data with other applications, consumers, producers that it cannot store locally?
architecture.description: In the use of digital services, data exchanges are both essential but generate a significant consumption of resources. Reducing trade needs to the strict minimum reduces the impact of such trade. Only the global view of flows with their sources, destinations and objectives makes it possible to qualify the need and accept the impact of the consumption they generate.

architecture.title: Are the security, accessibility, and Responsible Digital aspects treated in the same way for each element of the architecture ?
architecture.test: Do the architectural processes and frameworks systematically integrate security, accessibility and Responsible Digital aspects?
architecture.description: Organizations are structured so that the architecture phase integrates security aspects very early on in the process. Security must be addressed for all elements of the architecture. As security is not the only area that applies across the board, it must be combined with the other subjects: accessibility and sustainable IT. Each element of the architecture must be treated with the same excellence for security, accessibility and Sustainable IT.

architecture.title: Is the traceability of security requirements guaranteed ?
architecture.test: What are the safety monitoring indicators defined and are they based on reliable and proven data?
architecture.description: The security of information systems impacts the activity of the organization and the respect and confidence of users. Safety is not a given, it must be questioned periodically and the monitoring and validation procedures must be traced.

architecture.title: Does the use of the service exclude certain software or hardware configurations ?
architecture.test: Does the new version of the service or product require new external components?
architecture.description: When the design of a service increases the technical requirements of the environments in which it is suitable to operate, whether on the server side or on user devices, this leads at best to a new dimensioning of these hardware components, at worst the need to replace them with a more powerful range. In any case, this generates a strong environmental footprint not to mention the fact that it excludes certain users who do not have the equipment.

architecture.title: Does the use of the service make it possible to envisage software or hardware configurations that have less impact on the environment ?
architecture.test: What low-tech solutions are being considered?
architecture.description: Technological escalation to the detriment of the environment is not sustainable. The architecture phase must take into consideration how to fulfill the functionalities while limiting the impacts of the technology.

architecture.title: Does the added value of the framework justify the weighting of the application ?
architecture.test: Is the use of a framework essential to implement the requested functionalities?
architecture.description: The alternatives between solutions developed in-house and the use of frameworks must take into account Responsible Digital aspects. The frameworks provide more functionalities than necessary for the project and integrate components and dependencies to fulfill the totality of the offered functionalities. The relationship between the functionalities provided by the framework and those actually sought is critical. The choice of the framework must also make it possible to restrict its functional scope to only the elements essential for the service.

architecture.title: Does the frequency of use of the feature require it to be available all the time or can it be updated in the background (batch) ?
architecture.test: Are recurring and predictable operations implemented as a batch rather than a web service?
architecture.description: Exceeding expectations can lead to offering solutions that are close to real time, providing the results of an operation as quickly and as often as possible. Users or customers, in a technical sense, very rarely need this solution, or even are overwhelmed by information faster than they can or wish to digest it. Reducing the number of instant operations and managing the time between these operations by processing them in the background reduces service costs.

architecture.title: Is the app quick to start / stop ?
architecture.test: Is the cold start time monitored as the development iterations progress?
architecture.description: Technical performance is often an indicator of environmental performance. The lighter a service (volume of exchange, processing) the faster it is launched and the less resources it consumes.

architecture.title: Are algorithms and processing optimized in the application ?
architecture.test: Is a performance audit carried out within the application / component / microservice with identification of bottlenecks, resources used, ...?
architecture.description: Certain treatments are systematically triggered, even if individually they are not very impactful, their number of occurrences will impact the overall footprint. By working at the algorithm level of each treatment, this optimization is possible.

architecture.title: Is the ability to evolve / modify the application studied ?
architecture.test: Is the application in microservice mode?
architecture.description: Responsible Digital is a process of continuous improvement which should allow progress to be made in reducing impacts.

architecture.title: Is a compiled language used for performance and / or security aspects ?
architecture.test: Is the code the object of optimization before compilation, or failing interpretation?
architecture.description: The type of language used introduces either a proximity to processors (CPU), this is the case of compiled languages, or to humans, this is the case of interpreted languages ​​(PHP, JavaScript, ...). The proximity of machine orders increases technical performance but makes software production heavier (compilation phases, link editing). The "human" proximity facilitates development but also embezzlement (piracy) and requires systems an additional effort to translate program lines "on demand" into machine code, with the help of an interpreter.

architecture.title: Are the benchmarks known, kept up to date, and made available to the entire project team ?
architecture.test: How is the degree of compliance assessed?
architecture.description: The use of stable references is essential to maintain a consistent approach

architecture.title: Is the inventory of the input data made available for reuse in other projects ?
architecture.test: What data is used as input and produced for other projects?
architecture.description: The Sustainable IT principles are stable and the best practices deployed can be used directly in other project contexts, especially since the projects within an organization have many similarities whether in methods, objectives, scopes functional. In the specification phase, collecting, preparing and producing these elements is a guarantee of efficiency and reliability to increase the maturity of the organization in its Sustainable IT practices.

architecture.title: Are the functionalities linked to regulated data processing (health, banking, etc.) validated in terms of interoperability ?
architecture.test: Is each functionality linked to regulated data identified?
architecture.description: The practice of professionals in regulated fields is guided by data security and reducing the impact of using the service.

architecture.title: Is the implementation of new services linked to regulated data necessary and, if so, does it build on the base of available services ?
architecture.test: Are the features not natively available in the service base?
architecture.description: The services must take into account the regulatory elements and reuse the maximum usual elements of these types of consolidated services in the form of a service base.

architecture.title: Are there any meetings planned so that the urbanization unit assesses the evolutions of the IS with regard to the design, the evolution put in place ?
architecture.test: How are requests for changes planned and evaluated?
architecture.description: Sustainable IT issues are never definitively established and must be periodically monitored

architecture.title: Are all the technical equipment used by the service identified ?
architecture.test: What equipment will need to be purchased or replaced?
architecture.description: Design, development, tests, production, availability management are steps that will use technical resources. Each of these resources must be identified and its characteristics listed.

architecture.title: Does the organization's master plan propose Responsible Digital objectives and actions that will influence architectural design or urbanization solutions ?
architecture.test: Does the master plan take into account Sustainable IT objectives?
architecture.description: The integration of Responsible Digital into the company's strategy is essential for this concept to be propagated in all the functions of the organization. In the absence of this global strategy, only a preliminary study makes it possible to position the general objectives and to determine the action levers that will be implemented.

architecture.title: Are the Sustainable IT goals qualified ?
architecture.test: What indicators (Carbon, WEEE, ...) are exposed to users?
architecture.description: Adherence to the SDGs and Sustainable IT principles must be verified to assess the distance traveled and remaining in relation to the objectives. The qualification of objectives in the form of indicators is an essential preliminary operation

architecture.title: For each equipment, are the characteristics available ?
architecture.test: Are the thresholds defined for considering replacement?
architecture.description: The position of the equipment in its life cycle and its environmental footprint must be known in order to make the best use of the available equipment.

architecture.title: Is each function of the service understood in terms of its importance in the service ?
architecture.test: Have you applied an 80/20 approach for each function in relation to its environmental footprints and its importance?
architecture.description: The most important functions sometimes consume less resources than marginal functions, which does not make sense in a coherent Sustainable IT approach.

architecture.title: Do secondary functions also have a lower impact on the environmental footprint ?
architecture.test: Are the rules for validating the Sustainable IT impacts of the functions described?
architecture.description: Sustainable IT consistency pushes to ensure that the secondary functions do not have a greater environmental footprint than the main functions, the specifications must clearly identify the main and secondary functions and their impact from a Sustainable IT point of view

architecture.title: Are each of the life cycle phases (Start-up, maturity, shutdown) identified with specific actions ?
architecture.test: How often are these actions reviewed?
architecture.description: The LCA approach is a basis for taking into account Sustainable IT in the design of digital services, it allows actions to be associated at each stage of the life cycle.

architecture.title: Are LCA data reused in the event of an adaptation of an existing service ?
architecture.test: What LCA data is produced to allow its reuse in other projects?
architecture.description: LCA analyzes can be carried out on existing services in order to make them more efficient in the case of a redesign or adaptation of an existing service

architecture.title: Is the duration of digital service support sufficient to minimize equipment renewal ?
architecture.test: Did the calculation for the duration of service or product support take into account the impact on equipment renewal?
architecture.description: The need to adapt equipment to operating services can be a source of significant environmental footprint.

architecture.title: Is documentary production researched / reviewed / used upstream of the process and produced downstream to be re-used in the following projects ?
architecture.test: What is the frequency of peer review of documents?
architecture.description: On the one hand, in an organization the projects present many similarities, on the other hand the Sustainable IT aspects addressed in the projects are often of the same order. In order to capitalize on these elements and benefit from the efforts produced, it is necessary to rely on a stable knowledge base. However, the maturity of an organization from a Sustainable IT point of view is bound to progress, it is therefore necessary that the documented stages can also follow these evolutions and actively participate in this increase in maturity.

architecture.title: Does each stakeholder have the latitude to make decisions that may influence the environmental footprint ?
architecture.test: Is the decision-making process exposed to everyone?
architecture.description: Project decisions that can have a significant impact on the environment must be able to be taken quickly. For this, it is essential to define the decision-making space of each actor and the validation mechanisms. In the absence of this clarification, erratic decisions, even for good reasons, could intervene and discredit the Sustainable IT approach, or lead to a form of self-censorship limiting the Sustainable IT benefits.

architecture.title: Are Responsible Digital aspects propagated and maintained across all stakeholders ?
architecture.test: How many players in the Architecture department are aware of and trained in Responsible Digital?
architecture.description: Project definitions may change over time. These changes must systematically take into account the Sustainable IT aspects. Adaptations are most often the result of trades or technical requirements. Environmental impacts must also be able to have this latitude with pre-defined validation paths.

architecture.title: Are Responsible Digital goals qualified for each type of audience in architectural design ?
architecture.test: How are the achieved objectives valued?
architecture.description: To clearly express the Sustainable IT objectives in each of the architectural design stages, it is essential to locate the target profiles and associate them with specific Sustainable IT objectives.

architecture.title: Does the architect have a role in the continuity of the product ?
architecture.test: Is the scope of action extended to the different project phases?
architecture.description: Each project stage must endeavor to take into account the most complete possible coverage of the product life cycle.

architecture.title: Does the animation of the project team include a Responsible Digital dimension ?
architecture.test: Are Responsible Digital reviews planned throughout the project?
architecture.description: The taking into account of the Sustainable IT aspects made at the start of the design can be respected but in an iterative mode it is possible to gradually deviate from it. Sustainable IT compliance reviews are essential to maintain the consistency of the project.

backend.title: Is the number of requests kept to a minimum (no looping) ?
backend.test: How many queries are used for a given user request?
backend.description: Since each exchange consumes resources on both the sender and the recipient ends, the number of these exchanges should be kept to a minimum.

backend.title: Is an alternative to SQL queries used when possible (local storage or similar) ?
backend.test: What data could be stored locally?
backend.description: Database management engines provide powerful technical solutions but at the expense of complex and therefore resource-intensive technical mechanisms. Sometimes simpler solutions provide a similar result with less wasted resources.

backend.title: Do implemented queries use joins rather than multiple queries ?
backend.test: Is the performance of joins optimized?
backend.description: The data access mechanisms can generate significant processing times and therefore a significant use of resources. Most often these loads are associated with a user session and therefore multiply with the increase in traffic on the service. DBMS engines offer several effective analysis mechanisms with regard to the organization of data and needs. Reducing the data access load for a user session is environmentally beneficial and efficient for the technical performance of the service.

backend.title: Can data be backed up incrementally ?
backend.test: What is the cumulative volume of backups over a month?
backend.description: One piece of data might be present in several different environments, notably on each backup. This will consume space and transfer flows if the backups are outsourced. The presence of unmodified data on all sets of backups brings very little value compared to the cost involved. Incremental backup solutions should be implemented to reduce the impact of this essential security.

backend.title: Is the removal of obsolete data being managed ?
backend.test: Are data lifetimes managed?
backend.description: The regulations require control of the data life cycle for certain categories (for e.g.: personal data governed by the RGPD). Lack of consideration to other categories of data leads to the accumulation of data without taking into account their expiry dates, which increases the volume of data, the volume of backups and the resources consumed by accessing the data. Over time, the level of detail of the data becomes less important, which should lead to a reduction in the volume of data, preceding its eventual removal.

backend.title: Are database indexes consistent with operations ?
backend.test: Is index performance reviewed periodically?
backend.description: The organization of data has a strong impact on the search performance in a DBMS. The rules for structuring data collections make it possible to optimize these points. DBMS engines also have performance indicators that facilitate optimization procedures. Less time and processing to access data means less energy consumption and less need to oversize the servers that host these engines.

backend.title: Is an alternative to the relational model being considered ?
backend.test: Is a NoSql solution in place?
backend.description: Relational DBMS models offer efficient solutions for managing highly segmented data structures, but on the other hand these DBMS engines are more resource intensive. Alternative models may be more efficient (NoSQL) for certain categories of usage.

backend.title: Is a NoSql solution more efficient than its relational equivalent ?
backend.test: What would be the benefits of a NoSql solution?
backend.description: It is difficult to predict the performance advantage between relational and NoSql models, as it is highly dependent on the organisation and the use of the data collections. Only a comparative study on a sample can establish the gains and benefits of each alternative.

backend.title: Have the different data access solutions (queries, triggers, stored procedures) been tested ?
backend.test: Are the performances of the different solutions (triggers, stored procedures, queries) known?
backend.description: The different methods of accessing data provided by DBMS engines can produce different resource consumption for a similar result. Among these solutions, queries, stored procedures, triggers should be evaluated to determine the best fit for each use, which would reduce resource consumption.

backend.title: Are EXPLAIN clauses used on "Slow queries" to optimize indexes ?
backend.test: Are the criteria for identifying a slow query clearly defined?
backend.description: Most DBMS engines have a supervision mode as standard which allows the identification of the most resource-intensive actions. Some DBMS provide methods for investigating processes identified as "heavy". This helps to identify areas for improvement to reduce the time and cost of operations.

backend.title: Are the slow query detection thresholds set effectively ?
backend.test: Are the slow query thresholds reviewed periodically?
backend.description: Even if the data structure does not change, the volumes will change between the design and the use of the service. This volume may lead to load phenomena or resource constraints that were not previously apparent. Monitoring the evolution of the most consuming processes is essential throughout the life of the service.

backend.title: Are "live" and "dead" data handled differently (eg: Slow storage for "dead" data) ?
backend.test: How much inactive data is kept?
backend.description: Historical data must be retained for legal reasons or service functionality. The usage rates of inactive data do not justify the use of high performance storage systems. The most efficient storage solutions are also often those that consume the most energy or have the shortest lifespan.

backend.title: Is frequently accessed data available in RAM ?
backend.test: What rate of physical access to data is being measured?
backend.description: The consumption of processing resources is higher when information has to be collected on physical media (disks, networks) rather than in RAM memory. The most frequently accessed data should benefit from this solution to reduce the energy of access, and reduce the need of high performance.

backend.title: Are data replications between multiple Database Engine (Cluster) instances appropriate for sensitivity and availability requirement ?
backend.test: Is the duplicated data tracked and linked to its sensitivity?
backend.description: The same data can be duplicated to ensure availability and security. Redundancy is effective in securing data, but not all data justifies this precaution, which increases storage volumes and generates additional synchronisation processes. Only sensitive data should be secured with the most efficient redundancy mechanisms. Clustering of DBMS allows to manage the failure of an engine. However, if in addition each engine uses some redundant storage (Mirroring, RAID 5, ...) the same data ends up with a footprint that can be multiplied by 6 (most often a cluster contains 3 instances to manage the quorums in case of failure of a node).

backend.title: Does the data have an expiration date when it is deleted ?
backend.test: How often are expiration dates checked?
backend.description: The specifications reveal data collections of asynchronous procedures or periodic tasks essential for the proper functioning of the service. These elements are most often invisible and in the absence of explicit specifications of the withdrawal process they are rarely taken into account for the purposes of operating a service. Each of these elements should carry its own end-of-life information.

backend.title: Is sensitive data collected ?
backend.test: How much data is identified as sensitive under the GDPR?
backend.description: The data that users entrust are under your responsibility and users must be kept informed of the care you take to ensure the confidentiality of this data. The GDPR imposes a framework for personal data but does not cover other categories that deserve the same precautions. The processing register, the GDPR PIA must be carried out, updated and validated by the DPO (Data Protection Officer). Data exchanged with other service providers must be subject to a liability analysis. Limiting the collection of sensitive data, beyond respect for the user, also reduces the burden and responsibility of administering this personal data.
backend.score: Number of private data analyzed / Number of private data

backend.title: Is sensitive data collected ?
backend.test: How much data is identified as sensitive under the GDPR?
backend.description: The data that users entrust are under your responsibility and users must be kept informed of the care you take to ensure the confidentiality of this data. The GDPR imposes a framework for personal data but does not cover other categories that deserve the same precautions. The processing register, the GDPR PIA must be carried out, updated and validated by the DPO (Data Protection Officer). Data exchanged with other service providers must be subject to a liability analysis. Limiting the collection of sensitive data, beyond respect for the user, also reduces the burden and responsibility of administering this personal data.
backend.score: Number of private data analyzed / Number of private data

backend.title: Does the API provide limits, filters and the list of fields to return ?
backend.test: What is the maximum output returned by APIs?
backend.description: User behavior and needs are very difficult to anticipate. There is a tendency to provide the front end with as much data as possible to cover the maximum number of use cases. This practice is inefficient from a Sustainable IT point of view as the collection, processing and routing of data generates a load and therefore a significant energy consumption without any certainty that all this data will actually be used. The service footprint should be reduced by collecting only the necessary data.
backend.score: Number of API data collected analyzed / Number of API data collected

backend.title: Is sensitive user data secure ?
backend.test: What safeguards are in place for sensitive data?
backend.description: The GDPR requires the implementation of a PIA, which must be effectively monitored and integrated into the quality processes. Beforehand, all solutions for securing sensitive data should be deployed and validated.
backend.score: Number of sensitive data analyzed / Number of sensitive data

backend.title: Does regulated data (personal, health, financial) comply with the recommendations for structuring these categories of data ?
backend.test: How much of the regulated data is used?
backend.description: The regulatory framework for certain categories of data is very strict, and protection of this data is an important criterion. It is essential that in the development process no gaps are left and that interoperability with standard mechanisms in these areas is validated.

backend.title: Is the documentation of the functionality available to enable its reuse ?
backend.test: What design information is being documented for reuse in other projects?
backend.description: In an organisation, projects have many similarities, and the Sustainable IT aspects addressed in the projects are often of the same order. In order to capitalise on these elements and benefit from the efforts made, it is necessary to rely on a stable knowledge base. However, the maturity of an organisation from a Sustainable IT point of view is bound to progress, so the documented steps must also be able to follow these developments and actively participate in increasing this maturity.

backend.title: Is the web server used asynchronous and multi-threaded ?
backend.test: Which http server is used?
backend.description: The physical architectures of the servers have mechanisms to optimize the management of threads. The software must be able to exploit these functionalities to optimize the use of physical resources to limit the need for over-sizing of the equipment to handle the operational load of the services.

backend.title: Has the dependency tree of the integrated components been evaluated ?
backend.test: Is the dependency graph generated?
backend.description: Very often components from public libraries (open source or commercial) provide a set of functionalities that are rarely used, and drain dependencies on other components with the same characteristics. In the end, the project aggregates a large volume of libraries while only a small part is actually used. Favouring components whose dependencies and functionalities are controllable in relation to needs is efficient from the Sustainable IT point of view.

backend.title: Can dependencies be reduced by using an alternative component ?
backend.test: Is the dependency graph available for each component?
backend.description: Dependency trees provide a mapping of components and their relationships. A dependency tree that is as small as possible is efficient because it reduces the amount of code, but it does not imply that each branch of the dependency tree is being used for an actual purpose.

backend.title: Is the user informed of a processing in progress in the background ?
backend.test: Is there a list of treatments that do not require an immediate outcome?
backend.description: Some processing is invisible from the user's point of view, but may produce delays in response that are not recognised by the user and may lead to repeat operations. The multiplication of unnecessary processing requests degrades Sustainable IT performance.

backend.title: Has the integration of asynchronous processing been evaluated ?
backend.test: Is the impact of delay assessed?
backend.description: Deferred processing of operations allows the demands for loads on the systems to be spread over a longer period of time.

backend.title: Are unused resources freed up as quickly as possible ?
backend.test: Is local data released as soon as it is no longer needed?
backend.description: Development techniques free developers from explicit allocation and release of resources used. However, the volume of resources is conditioned by the scope of the information and the extensive use of data will result in an overload of consumption which may lead to an over-sizing of the equipment. A more rational use of ressources would allow to avoid this.

backend.title: Is a VM necessary as opposed to a container solution ?
backend.test: Is the Sustainable IT impact assessed for each solution?
backend.description: Virtual Machine virtualization techniques duplicate all operating systems and partition access to physical components. Other container-based techniques are more economical in terms of duplication and their proximity to the physical components allow better use and supervision of these resources.

backend.title: Does service availability require redundancy ?
backend.test: Is the SLA defined?
backend.description: Redundancy makes it possible to guarantee a high level of service. This solution however requires a considerable duplication of physical equipment, networks and storage. This fault tolerance is sometimes justified by the functionality of the service, and sometimes goes beyond the requirements. Adapting the level of service and the need for the service allows the environmental impact to be reduced.

backend.title: Do interactions between components benefit from caching mechanisms ?
backend.test: What caching mechanism is implemented for the interactions between components?
backend.description: The reduction of the volumes of exchanges, of operations of calculations, processing, and access to data is an axis of optimization of the consumption of resources. The implementation of caching mechanisms reduces the costs of repetitive operations. Caching of data may occur at different levels (computers) in a software system. The closer the cache is to the requestor that it is to serve, the smaller the volume of data in transit and the length of the path taken by the data. The closer the cache is to the data source, the more it can be shared by a large number of users, but the data will still be exchanged, only the processing and collection operations will be reduced.

backend.title: Are the browser caches not being blocked by the framework or technology used ?
backend.test: Is the browser cache being used?
backend.description: The use of certain frameworks, in particular in the case of single page applications, makes it difficult to manage the cache on the user device. The technologies used and the underlying design should limit such effects, which would overload the need for exchanges when there is no need for them.

backend.title: Is there a lighter framework / library that meets the functional need ?
backend.test: Is the study of the envisaged frameworks available and reviewed?
backend.description: For an equal functional scope, several technical solutions are possible. The more the framework is reduced, the more its environmental footprint will be reduced because flows will be minimized and consumption of processing resources reduced. The same applies to the technical performance.

backend.title: Is an Open Source solution available for the functional need ?
backend.test: Are Open Source solutions also evaluated against thei Sustainable IT criteria?
backend.description: An Open Source solution is not a guarantee of Sustainable IT practices and it should be compared to other available alternatives. However, Open Source allows to limit the ambitions and control of certain actors whose economic and social practices are opaque.

backend.title: Are the versions of the components used tracked and deployed ?
backend.test: How often are components updated?
backend.description: Capitalising on deployed best practice is a guarantee of environmental and operational efficiency. As technical advances are rapid, it is important to rapidly deploy all the environmental benefits that could be integrated into a component.

backend.title: Is the security implemented justified with regard to the operations carried out ?
backend.test: Is each operation associated with a security requirement?
backend.description: The implementation of security generates an additional environmental footprint that should be related to the critical aspect of the operation concerned, rather than being just a general practice. This segmentation of security level should have an overall benefit, and not generate additional impact costs.

backend.title: Is the level of logs adapted to the environment ?
backend.test: Are trace and debug log levels disabled in production?
backend.description: The deployment of services is linked to the collection of information that allows its control, such as anomaly events and debugging execution traces. These automatically generated logs are useful if they are actually used to make the service more reliable, but are a waste of resources when they are collected and ignored.

backend.title: Are temporary files included in the "logrotate" ?
backend.test: Are automatic deletions of temporary files supported?
backend.description: During the runtime, temporary files are produced. These files, after their occasional use, should be deleted from the storage spaces. Mechanisms for cleaning up these temporary files are available on all operating systems and should be implemented.
backend.score: Number of temporary files checked / Number of temporary files

backend.title: Is the data exchanged compressed before transmission ?
backend.test: What gain is obtained by compression?
backend.description: The essential exchanges should make it possible to reduce the volume of transfers. Minification of exchanges and compression of data exchanged allows to reduce these volumes. However, the compression and decompression operations require the execution of processes which can cancel out the benefit of the compression of exchanges.
backend.score: Size of network transfer compressed / Size of network transfer

backend.title: Is pagination used on data exchanges ?
backend.test: Are the data volumes transmitted consistent with the capacity of the user's device?
backend.description: The capacity of the user devices to retrieve information is limited. In addition, the user's ability to process data is also constrained. It would be inefficient if the volume of data transmitted were to exceed these limits, as this would lead to a wasteful use of processing resources.
backend.score: Size of network transfer compressed / Size of network transfer

backend.title: Is the number of requests between the client and the server kept to a minimum ?
backend.test: How many requests are needed for a user journey?
backend.description: The operations carried out on the front end generate requests to the remote services. The greater the number of requests, the more resources the processing and exchange mechanisms will consume. The scope and design of the back-end requests should make it possible to limit the number of requests.
backend.score: Size of network transfer compressed / Size of network transfer

backend.title: Does the data exchanged match the immediate need only ?
backend.test: Does the scope of requests corresponds to the intended usage?
backend.description: The scope and design of the back-end requests should make it possible to limit the volume of data exchanged to meet user needs as it goes along, without making hypothetical predictions of usage scenarios.
backend.score: Size of network transfer compressed / Size of network transfer

backend.title: Are user notifications necessary ?
backend.test: What notification solutions are used?
backend.description: The notification methods can use resource-consuming technologies and certain practices aim to multiply them which increases the environmental footprint of the service. Reducing notifications, using lightweight mechanisms, and allowing the user to disable these notifications is useful to reduce energy consumption and user distraction.
backend.score: Number of notifications analyzed / Number of notifications

backend.title: Is SSO implemented when possible ?
backend.test: Are the identification phases simplified?
backend.description: The reduction of user identification operations reduces the processing and security load.

backend.title: What would be my dev reflex, to take into account the life cycle ?
backend.test: What procedures are available to address the lifecycle?
backend.description: Consideration of the cycle must be integrated into the development phases. Developers are the main players who, through their choices, their practices will condition future results. Taking the life cycle into account in development is essential. It would be more expensive, riskier and less efficient to deal with downstream lifecycle aspects.

backend.title: Does each stakeholder have the latitude to make decisions that may influence the environmental footprint ?
backend.test: Is the the level of autonomy and the decision-making process having a Sustainable IT impact defined for each actor?
backend.description: The orientations of the developments may change over time. These developments should systematically take into account the Sustainable IT aspects. Adaptations are most often made by the business lines. Technical constraints that appear during development and generate environmental impacts should also be handled by the technical teams with pre-defined validation paths.

backend.title: Is code analysis used in the continuous integration process ?
backend.test: Are all product codes analyzed?
backend.description: The standardization and verification of conformity of product codes makes it possible to identify compliance with Sustainable IT recommendations and to refine the monitoring of these practices.
backend.score: Number of code lines analyzed / Number of code lines

backend.title: Are code quality metrics being tracked ?
backend.test: Are the faults traced and reviewed with their impact on Sustainable IT?
backend.description: The quality of the software produced has a direct impact on the Sustainable IT aspects. Defects lead to multiple deliveries of successive new versions, anomalies lead to the production of errors, and to functionalities that consume more resources, sometimes without achieving any result, so that in the end resources were used to no avail.

backend.title: Are functionality test reports available and tracked ?
backend.test: Are the identified Sustainable IT improvements systematically taken into account?
backend.description: Functional tests and test cases allow to increase the reliability of developments and to avoid inefficient software operations that require multiple updates and consume resources without providing needed functionality. In addition to user dissatisfaction, development teams are also frustrated because they have to deal with poor quality without being able to progress in their jobs.

backend.title: Have the tools for monitoring Sustainable IT performance been identified and made available to developers ?
backend.test: Is the list of tools published?
backend.description: Technical advances in Sustainable IT will make it possible to provide tools that facilitate the implementation and monitoring of Sustainable IT performance. The tools referenced to assist developments will multiply with the increase in Sustainable IT maturity of all organizations. The first tools available were focused on uses from a user point of view, the only tools for server-side processing are those used for monitoring technical performance. However, the technical performance and Sustainable IT advance mostly in the same direction.

backend.title: Has an analysis of the application's consumption profile been performed ?
backend.test: How often is this analysis reviewed?
backend.description: The resource consumption of codes can be analysed with tools that trace all the calls and the costs of each function or method. This consumption profile is a good starting point for reducing service consumption. Depending on usage, the profile may need to change and should be monitored regularly.

backend.title: Does each version deployed follow the same process for qualifying for Sustainable IT performance ?
backend.test: How many updates are deployed per year?
backend.description: Each update can improve the environmental impact of the service or negate it if these Sustianable IT principles are not systematically applied to each application maintenance operation. To maintain consistency and capitalise on the efforts and benefits made, the maintenance phases should follow the same approaches

backend.title: Is the overview of data handling processes (GDPR) available ?
backend.test: Is the data handling validated by the DPO?
backend.description: The data that users entrust are under your responsibility and users must be kept informed of the care you take to ensure the confidentiality of this data. The processing register, the GDPR PIA must be carried out, updated and validated by the DPO (Data Protection Officer). Data exchanged with other service providers must be subject to a liability analysis. Limiting the collection of sensitive data, beyond respect for the user, also reduces the burden and responsibility of administering this personal data.

Limiting the collection of sensitive data, beyond respect for the user, also reduces the burden and responsibility of administering this personal data.

backend.title: Is the RGAA taken into account ?
backend.test: Is personal data identified?
backend.description: Failure to comply with regulations is first of all illegal and can lead to significant penalties. It also cuts users off from access to the service even outside the disability context.

backend.title: Is regulated data (banking, health, etc.) secure ?
backend.test: Does the payment system comply with current security standards?
backend.description: The regulatory framework for certain categories of data is very strict, and protection of this data is an important criterion. It is essential that in the development process no gaps are left and that interoperability with standard mechanisms in these areas is validated.

backend.title: Is regulated data (banking, health, etc.) secure ?
backend.test: Does the payment system comply with current security standards?
backend.description: The regulatory framework for certain categories of data is very strict, and protection of this data is an important criterion. It is essential that in the development process no gaps are left and that interoperability with standard mechanisms in these areas is validated.

backend.title: Does the service being designed comply with changes in society and in legislation ?
backend.test: Is the legal department consulted?
backend.description: Beyond the purely regulatory aspects, anticipating the evolution of societal expectations is necessary to ensure long-term sustainability of the service. Anticipating future regulations and standards allows the service to be sustainable by limiting the need for updates dictated by the legal environment.

backend.title: Can the infrastructure provider disclose its environmental metrics ?
backend.test: What metrics are collected?
backend.description: From the Sustainable IT perspective, all human, environmental and economic aspects are important. Ensuring that all stakeholders, including contractors (and one's own subcontractors and suppliers) used for the project, have the same Sustainable IT considerations is necessary so that the coherence of the Sustainable IT efforts is not lost due to a choice that could have been avoided.

backend.title: Is the envisioned functionality useful ?
backend.test: Is each functionality associated with an identified use?
backend.description: The selection of functionalities deemed essential may be questioned in their initial form in relation to their Sustainable IT impact. In this case, the costs / benefits will have to take into account these oppositions and be subject to adaptation to bring together the 2 approaches: functional necessity and Sustainable IT impact.
backend.score: Number of features validated / Number of features

backend.title: Are the Sustainable IT aspects propagated and maintained across all stakeholders ?
backend.test: How many actors in the department are made aware of and trained in Sustainable IT?
backend.description: When each of the players has easy access to markers to assess the environmental footprint of their actions and choices, they can adapt their practices to make the service more efficient and sustainable.

backend.title: Was a benchmark on the environmental criteria carried out for the choice of the infrastructure supplier ?
backend.test: What acceptability thresholds are defined?
backend.description: Suppliers able to disclose their environmental criteria display a higher level of maturity and commitment. This should be taken into account when choosing a supplier.

backend.title: Does the design process / tools integrate the treatment of Sustainable IT requirements ?
backend.test: How many Sustainable IT requirements are associated with the project?
backend.description: Each feature implemented should take into account Sustainable IT so that the whole service is designed with the fullest respect for Sustainable IT principles, as one aspect not covered may negate all or part of the benefits gained elsewhere. It is more effective to have a balanced treatment across the whole, rather than aiming for excellence in one area and leaving significant gaps in others.

backend.title: Does the sizing of infrastructure resources follow the life of the application ?
backend.test: Is metrology defined and implemented?
backend.description: The utilisation rate of the physical resources of the infrastructure should be monitored to allow better use of the available hardware and to avoid deploying additional elements when the utilisation rate is incomplete.

backend.title: Is the technical architecture permanently in line with the activity of the service ?
backend.test: Are the monitoring of activity indicators related to optimization actions?
backend.description: Monitoring of usage rates should allow to reduce the size of the infrastructure when it is over-dimensioned in relation to the need.

backend.title: Is a summary of use cases of the features available ?
backend.test: Are non-core functionalities identified and addressed in a step-down approach?
backend.description: The User Story / Use Case should be specified in relation to uses in order to avoid an excessive number of functionalities which would be superfluous in relation to the real needs of users. Proposing non-core functionalities will result in an unjustified environmental footprint, cost and lack of understanding of the service.

backend.title: Are de-provisioning operations expressed at design time ?
backend.test: Are the de-provisioning processes described?
backend.description: During design, each part of the project may have to have a different lifespan. It is important that all end-of-life procedures are expressed so that the footprint of unused and discontinued components is zero.

backend.title: Are all the technical equipment used by the service identified ?
backend.test: Are the certifications for each equipment available?
backend.description: Design, development, tests, production, availability management are steps that will use technical resources. Each of these resources should be identified and have its characteristics listed.

backend.title: Are the characteristics available for each equipment (year of construction, environmental performance data...) ?
backend.test: Do the equipment renewal criteria take into account the Sustainable IT impacts?
backend.description: The point in the life cycle of the equipment and its environmental impact should be known in order to make the best use of the equipment available.

backend.title: Is each function of the service understood in terms of its importance in the service ?
backend.test: Has a 80/20 approach been applied for each function in relation to its environmental footprint and its importance?
backend.description: The most important functions sometimes consume less resources than non-core functions, which does not fit with a coherent Sustainable IT approach.

backend.title: Do secondary functions also have a lower impact on the environmental footprint ?
backend.test: Are the environmental footprints of each feature assessed against the nature and importance of the feature?
backend.description: The Sustainable IT is about ensuring that secondary functions do not have a greater environmental impact than primary functions. The development phases should clearly identify the primary and secondary functions and their impact from a Sustainable IT perspective

backend.title: Is each phase of the life cycle identified with specific actions ?
backend.test: How often are these actions reviewed?
backend.description: The LCA approach is a basis for taking into account Sustainable IT in the design of digital services, it allows actions to be associated at each stage of the life cycle.

backend.title: IsLCA data reused in the event of an adaptation of an existing service ?
backend.test: Are previous LCAs available to the project teams?
backend.description: LCA analyzes can be carried out on existing services in order to make them more efficient in the event of a redesign or adaptation of an existing service.

hosting.title: Is the waste from the data center recovered or recycled ?
hosting.test: Do you have the means to check the waste treatment process?
hosting.description: The treatment of waste generated by a data center is complex, it is therefore necessary to address it and consider its proper management in terms of recycling and respect for the environment.

hosting.title: Is PUE (Power Usage Effectivness) available ?
hosting.test: Is the PUE less than or equal to 1.2?
hosting.description: The total power consumed by the data center compared to the power consumed by the servers gives the overall efficiency of the entire infrastructure.

hosting.title: Does cooling affect groundwater ?
hosting.test: What temperature difference is tolerable for the water between the inlet and the outlet?
hosting.description: Water usage is associated with IT hosting services. Most often water circulates but degradation can come from both temperature and purity.

hosting.title: Does the location of the data center affect the ecosystem nearby ?
hosting.test: Where is the data center located, can it degrade a natural area, or affect humans?
hosting.description: Data centers are rarely installed in the heart of urban areas, they benefit from more favorable natural environments that they should not contribute to impoverish.

hosting.title: Is the quality of the water degraded by its use in the data center ?
hosting.test: Has the implementation of water collection and its discharge been verified?
hosting.description: The data center must be able to reuse the water it rejects.

hosting.title: Does the water used come from the drinking water supply ?
hosting.test: Is the water supply source verified?
hosting.description: There is no unnecessary water treatment required to cool the data center. Consequently, the use of drinking water is unnecessary.

hosting.title: Is the data center causing noise pollution ?
hosting.test: Are the dB measurements checked against environmental pollution?
hosting.description: In accordance with article L1382 of the Civil Code, any datacenter must take care to limit its noise pollution.

hosting.title: Is any of the produced indirect energy (heat) reused ?
hosting.test: What is the percentage of reuse?
hosting.description: The transformation of energy produces heat. In an effort to avoid releasing heat into the environment and to avoid the consumption of energy to produce heat in other activities, the heat of the data centers should be reused (heating of premises, water, greenhouses, ...)

hosting.title: Is the building LEED / BDM certified or equivalent ?
hosting.test: What is the construction certification?
hosting.description: The building structure can be more or less efficient in its design, the most efficient environmental standards of construction should be applied.

hosting.title: Is the cooling optimized based on accurate temperature analysis ?
hosting.test: Is cooling optimized based on real-time temperature analysis?
hosting.description: Each additional degree of cooling consumes energy; adapting the production of cooling to the instantaneous need reduces this consumption.

hosting.title: How and on what criteria is cooling optimized ?
hosting.test: Is the cooling control carried out automatically based on reliable data?
hosting.description: The operating temperatures and the level of hygrometry tolerances of the servers are broad, the cooling should be optimised to be within the upper values of these ranges.

hosting.title: Does the data center infrastructure take cooling constraints into account ?
hosting.test: Is the data center designed as a cold corridor or equivalent?
hosting.description: The organisation of the data centre can facilitate the management of cooling and airflows, allowing the reduction in the volume of air handled by the cooling system.

hosting.title: Are the server power supplies efficient ?
hosting.test: Are the server power supplies 80 Plus certified?
hosting.description: One factor in reducing the hosting footprint is the energy consumption of servers. The constantly evolving labels and certifications facilitate the choice of models of servers. Some equipment has several power sources. Redundant power supply management should also be included in the selection criteria

hosting.title: Is the occupancy rate of the datacenter rooms optimized to improve the energy balance ?
hosting.test: Is a minimum occupancy rate of 80% taken into account before opening another room?
hosting.description: The occupancy density of the racks in the hosting rooms should make it possible to favor the efficiency of shared equipment.
