hosting.description: The total water consumed by the data center gives the overall efficiency of the entire infrastructure.

hosting.title: Does the provider subscribe to best practives for datacenters ?
hosting.test: Does the datacenter follows European code of conduct for data centres ?
hosting.description: Datacenter business give more and more rules to deploy good practices and propose code of conduct?

hosting.title: Do all of the service provider's employees have social and salary conditions equivalent to those of the data center customer ?
hosting.test: Does the service provider use subcontractors outside the territory?
hosting.description: The 24/7 supervision needs of data centers can push operators to distribute their technical and human supervision resources in a "Follow the Sun" mode. The conditions of work in different countries can introduce great inequalities in treatment and social coverage. The transparency and consistency of treatment of all of the service provider's employees is essential to guarantee the human and economic dimension of Sustainable IT.

hosting.title: Is the data center located near the main activity ?
hosting.test: Have the needs, costs and impacts of travel on the data center been assessed?
hosting.description: Physical trips to datacenters are by nature infrequent, but synchronizations with on-site technical teams are sometimes essential. The distance must be minimized to reduce the impacts of these trips

hosting.title: Are trips for interventions to the data center possible by public transport or soft mobility ?
hosting.test: Are there different means of transport available to reach the datacenter?
hosting.description: The location of the data center in a perimeter accessible by low-emission mobility is more favourable for the few trips that would be necessary.

hosting.title: Are trips for interventions to the data center possible by public transport or soft mobility ?
hosting.test: Are there different means of transport available to reach the datacenter?
hosting.description: The location of the data center in a perimeter accessible by low-emission mobility is more favourable for the few trips that would be necessary.

hosting.title: Does the material come from companies known to respect the labor code ?
hosting.test: Is supply traceability guaranteed?
hosting.description: Data center hardware supply providers should be traceable to enable lifecycle analysis. Strict compliance with international labor standards should be valid.

hosting.title: Is the equipment made by environmentally friendly companies ?
hosting.test: Are suppliers' Sustainable IT indicators available?
hosting.description: The stance of data center equipment suppliers regarding sustainability should be disclosed and validated, to ensure the overview required by the life cycle analysis.

hosting.title: Is the size of the physical park in line with the number of virtual machines to be run ?
hosting.test: Is the allocation of physical resources relative to virtual machines monitored?
hosting.description: Virtualization techniques make it possible to pool the physical resources of a server and a storage space. This abstraction can optimize the use of equipment, but can also lead to underutilization of physical equipment and to a deployment of new equipment before the need is really present. The total environmental footprint of a server and its use is significant.

hosting.title: Are servers / routers turned off when not in use ?
hosting.test: Are shutdown procedures for unused servers in place?
hosting.description: The network infrastructure is at the heart of the architecture of data centers, redundancy and over-dimensioning mechanisms are widely deployed but used on an ad hoc basis. In the absence of need and when this does not impact the safety of the site, the excess equipment should be de-energized to reduce energy consumption and cooling needs.

hosting.title: Is the allocated memory based on actual use ?
hosting.test: What monitoring mechanisms are deployed?
hosting.description: The management of the consumption of physical resources involves data collection of the physical equipment and of all the virtual equipment it hosts. Recent virtualization techniques allow parameters to be changed without interruption to increase or decrease the resources (CPU / RAM) allocated to virtual machines, as needed, or even migrate virtual machines to less loaded physical servers.

hosting.title: Is the number of CPU cores allocated based on actual use ?
hosting.test: Is it possibl to size on the spot?
hosting.description: The CPU resources available to virtual machines are a combination of the number of processors, the number of cores in each processor and the hyper-threading capabilities. These CPU components form the basis of the virtual resources that the virtual machines can allocate.

hosting.title: Is the technical choice (shared, dedicated, clustered) optimised between the actual need and energy efficiency ?
hosting.test: Which metric drives the choice: technical, security, finance, scalability, physical footprint?
hosting.description: Different solutions offered by hosting providers generate very different physical equipment allocations and therefore a different environmental footprint. The major point of analysis is the number of servers, the power consumed by the servers, the storage volumes and the power consumed by them. Using powerful servers or storage for a need that does not require their full capacity increases environmental impact.

hosting.title: Are unused cores disabled ?
hosting.test: Are under and overload periods anticipated?
hosting.description: Hosted services do not always have the same performance needs and are subject to strong variations in load, during the day, week, month or year. The sizing are calibrated to accept the maximum loads which may be over limited time ranges. Outside of these periods, the need for power is reduced and the activity of the systems must be able to be reduced in the same proportions so as not to monopolize energy unnecessarily.

hosting.title: Is the backup system incremental (disk optimization) ?
hosting.test: What is the volume of daily backups?
hosting.description: Security is one of the key points of data centers and backups are one of the elements involved in this security. The volume of backups is cumulative. Individually, the volume of data to be backed up tends to grow, and the different backup sets multiply this effect. Unmodified data does not need to occupy backup spaces unnecessarily. Incremental backups reduce the environmental footprint of this process. Some solutions are able to provide such incremental backups, others, however, can only archive in full, which increases the environmental footprint.

hosting.title: Is the use of containers over virtual machines preferred ?
hosting.test: Is the comparative study for the service between VM and container available and does it consider the Sustainable IT impacts of each solution?
hosting.description: Virtual machines and containers are 2 virtualization techniques. Virtual machine technology uses a lot of duplications (operating system for example) and creates virtual components associated with physical components. The container mode is based on the physical components of the hardware and uses them more natively by limiting the duplications of software components. From a Sustainable IT point of view, containers are often more efficient but the technology is less widely deployed.

hosting.title: Are Open Source solutions implemented when available ?
hosting.test: Are Open Source solutions also evaluated against thei Sustainable IT criteria?
hosting.description: An Open Source solution is not a guarantee of Sustainable IT practices and it should be compared to other available alternatives. However, Open Source allows to limit the ambitions and control of certain actors whose economic and social practices are opaque.

hosting.title: Is high availability designed in a modular fashion ?
hosting.test: Is the need for security defined for each function?
hosting.description: The security needs are different depending on the clients and the hosted services. The same generic rule of excellence in this area is not always necessary. The design of high availability mechanisms, which involves many redundant components, should be able to adapt to real needs in order to reduce the impact of the services.

hosting.title: Is provisioning / deprovisionning dynamic depending on the load ?
hosting.test: How long after inactivity are the services de-provisioned?
hosting.description: When hosting a service, each component part may have a different lifetime. It is important that all end-of-life procedures are outlined so that the footprint of unused and discontinued components is neutral. This is also the case when the shutdown is temporary due to a drop in activity.

hosting.title: Do storage solutions reduce the number of components (for example: high density SSD media) ?
hosting.test: What is the ratio between the space consumed and the volume of data?
hosting.description: The density of the storage space determines the power consumption that the storage will require. Disk technologies are evolving rapidly, with moving parts tending to be replaced by electronic components that reduce overall power consumption.

hosting.title: Are the servers and technical equipment certified ?
hosting.test: Do the servers have a certification (ASHRAE, TCO8, ...)?
hosting.description: Environmental standards, labels and certifications are becoming more common. Servers, storage spaces and network equipment are increasingly demonstrating adherence to some of these standards. The emergence of new labels should be monitored to choose the best solution.

hosting.title: Does the supplier display all of its indicators ?
hosting.test: Which indicators are based on external data with reliable sources?
hosting.description: The level of Sustainable IT maturity of data centre operators varies greatly, but when Sustainable IT performance indicators are reported, this demonstrates advanced maturity. The communication of indicators, however, does not guarantee the relevance and reliability of these indicators, and that should also be explained.

hosting.title: Is the end-of-life equipment recycled or upcycled (sale / donation / recycling, etc.) ?
hosting.test: Is the chain traceable?
hosting.description: The renewal of the technical park is essential, the equipment capable of serving less intense uses should be reconditioned and re-injected into other sectors of activity. Equipment that cannot be put back into service must enter a reliable recycling channel and each step should be traced to ensure its compliance with Sustainable IT requirements.

hosting.title: Does the electricity come from renewable energies ?
hosting.test: Are the sources of energy supply known?
hosting.description: The activity of a data center requires energy. The energy sources will determine the environmental footprint. Low-carbon and renewable energy solutions will reduce this impact.

hosting.title: Does the datacenter provide reliable information in terms of energy consumption ?
hosting.test: IS the data published and verifiable?
hosting.description: The total energy consumption is useful for estimating the environmental footprint of the data centre. This should also take into account backup equipment (generators, UPS, etc.). However, having a breakdown of this consumption by usage is much more meaningful, as some indicators are only calculated with more precise data (e.g. PUE). In addition, such breakdown allows to identify the points that consume the most energy in order to implement actions to reduce them.

hosting.title: Does the electricity come from renewable energies ?
hosting.test: Are the sources of energy supply known?
hosting.description: The activity of a data center requires energy. The energy sources will determine the environmental footprint. Low-carbon and renewable energy solutions will reduce this impact.

hosting.title: Are the suppliers selected on the basis of their ability to communicate the differentiating indicators ?
hosting.test: What thresholds are defined as acceptability limits?
hosting.description: When selecting hosting service providers, the Sustainable IT aspects should be taken into account in the same way as if the service was handled in-house. In addition to the technical, budgetary and security considerations, the specifications should set out the Sustainable IT principles that the provider must fulfil.

hosting.title: Are the legal structure, its subsidiaries and its parent company respectful of regulations and ethics ?
hosting.test: Is all legal information collected and reviewed?
hosting.description: The hosting business is moving in two opposite directions: concentration of large players and the multiplication of local actors. While the legal structures of these two types of entities may be more or less visible, it is important to be able to understand all the ramifications in order to make an informed choice of provider in accordance with the Sustainable IT principles.

hosting.title: Is non-critical equipment obtained from reconditioning ?
hosting.test: Is the source of supply disclosed?
hosting.description: Extending the life of equipment reduces the need to replace equipment, and the use of refurbished equipment is an attractive practice in this respect. However, in some cases technological advances and the efficiency of technical components make new equipment a better choice that could consume less energy for the same usage.

hosting.title: Is the equipment repaired rather than replaced ?
hosting.test: Is the repair rate communicated?
hosting.description: The repairability of equipment, and the effective rate of repair is a criterion that makes it possible to reduce the environmental footprint of equipment over all of its lifespans.

hosting.title: Are servers and routers renewed when technologies allow better energy efficiency ?
hosting.test: Are equipment certifications available?
hosting.description: Technological advances and the efficiency of technical components can make it more useful to have recent equipment that will consume less energy for the same use.

hosting.title: Does the construction / sheath / insulation materials used allow for better energy efficiency. Does the building meet HQE, rt2012 or equivalent standards ?
hosting.test: What standard is used?
hosting.description: In addition to the building structure, which can be more or less efficient in its design, the building elements and related to the data center activity can also follow the most efficient environmental standards.

hosting.title: What is the impact of data center cooling on the environment ?
hosting.test: What type of cooling is used?
hosting.description: Cooling techniques involve either the production of cold from an energy source, or the capture of cold from a natural source. Energy consumption has a direct impact. Capture from a natural source of cold should also be assessed against the environmental impact of heat loss.

hosting.title: Are carbon / water efficiency measurements available ?
hosting.test: Are environmental efficiency measures available?
hosting.description: The standards for data centers highlight efficiency indicators that go beyond the energy part. Carbon and water efficiency metrics are increasingly used and allow a better assessment of data centers.

hosting.title: Does the hosting company apply a CSR / RGAA policy ?
hosting.test: Do support and operations teams operate under the same legal framework as the client?
hosting.description: Respecting human rights and people's interests is an important element of the Sustainable IT

hosting.title: Does the company provide reliable guarantees in terms of GDPR ?
hosting.test: Are compliance with French and European regulations as well as independence from regulations from a foreign country taken into account?
hosting.description: The GDPR requires to communicate the hosting details, this legal aspect must be checked thoroughly.

hosting.title: Are the hosting company's advantages presented when advancing Sustainable IT ?
hosting.test: What communication partnership is in place?
hosting.description: Some tools allow to check the characteristics of the hosting providers for websites, and their Sustainable IT practices. These tools allow then to add a "sticker" on a website to display this responsible choice. However, it is important to check the validity of the ratings given by these tools as sometimes their methodology of evaluation is obscure.

hosting.title: Is all data subject to regulation (health, banking) secured on a server with a compatible level of security ?
hosting.test: What are the hosting provider's certifications with regard to regulated data?
hosting.description: The regulations impose specific security levels for certain categories of data (health, banking). The standards evolve according to security needs and the latest technology. The validity of security levels should be monitored regularly to ensure that users of the service are not exposed to risks.

hosting.title: Is all data subject to regulation (health, banking) secured on a server with a compatible level of security ?
hosting.test: What are the hosting provider's certifications with regard to regulated data?
hosting.description: The regulations impose specific security levels for certain categories of data (health, banking). The standards evolve according to security needs and the latest technology. The validity of security levels should be monitored regularly to ensure that users of the service are not exposed to risks.

hosting.title: Does the supplier adhere to a standard / label ?
hosting.test: Has a charter been signed? Is the host provider part of a Sustainable IT network?
hosting.description: The data center operator may have launched a Sustainable IT initiative, and be able to demonstrate its commitment and actions towards Sustainable IT goals.

hosting.title: Is the datacenter at least Tier 3 ?
hosting.test: What is the security level of the data center?
hosting.description: The level of security of the data centre determines the accessibility of digital services.

hosting.title: Does the operator have several interconnected datacenters that are more than 100 km away ?
hosting.test: Does it conform to an ISO standard?
hosting.description: The impacts of natural or industrial disasters can render certain sites inoperative. In order to guarantee service continuity, the distances between the various sites hosting the services must take these elements into account.

hosting.title: Is the datacenter certification appropriate for the need and the geographic location (seismic, flooding) ?
hosting.test: Have the physical risks been assessed throughout the life of the project?
hosting.description: The characteristics of geographic areas may require specific provisions that data centers must take into account.

hosting.title: Does the physical access control to the site use biometric data ?
hosting.test: What guarantees are offered in terms of securing access data, operation, storage, lifespan?
hosting.description: The capture of biometric information helps secure access, but transmits important personal data that must be protected.

hosting.title: Does the data center provide a locally based digital vault solution ?
hosting.test: What technology, level of security, encryption is used for the digital vault?
hosting.description: Hosting critical data in a highly secure and encrypted space is sometimes essential to ensure the sustainability of the organization

hosting.title: Do the processes put in place for the prevention of incidents take into account the non-degradability of servers and equipment ?
hosting.test: How often are safety equipment tested?
hosting.description: The incident response procedures must first and foremost protect people and their data, but the destruction of physical equipment generates a need for a replacement with its impact on the environment.

hosting.title: Is the environmental impact of implementing each function appropriate to its importance ?
hosting.test: Has a 80/20 approach been applied for each function in relation to its environmental footprint and its importance?
hosting.description: The Sustainable IT consistency pushes to ensure that the secondary functions do not have a greater environmental footprint than the main functions. The specifications should clearly identify the main and secondary functions and their impact from a Sustainable IT perspective.

hosting.title: Has each phase of the life cycle been identified with specific actions ?
hosting.test: How often are these actions reviewed?
hosting.description: The LCA approach is a basis for taking into account Sustainable IT in the design of digital services, it allows actions to be associated at each stage of the life cycle.

hosting.title: Is data from previous studies available and kept up to date ?
hosting.test: What LCA data is produced to allow its reuse in other projects?
hosting.description: LCA analyzes can be carried out on existing services in order to make them more efficient in the event of a redesign or adaptation of an existing service.
